`Hi Paul

column1: Just to add to your argument about the popularity of Bossi's grammar in Milan. I've recently located a stationer's shop from that city (ASM
column2: notarile
column4: f. 24498) in which the presence of Bossi is particularly striking. The inventory lists 70 dozen (840 copies) "regole Bosso" with a wholesale price of just under 2 soldi/copy. Alvares' grammar ("emanuel") appears on the list too
column6: each listed at 16 soldi/copy.     \

column1: Also recorded in quantity and variety are donati ("al sena"; "al vocaboli") and the *regola* of Guarino (in one case combined with the donato). Like Bossi's work
column2: these are described as being sold in bundles of 12 (dozzina)** and priced as such. Wholesale prices fall in a narrow range
column3: from 1 soldo for the cheapest donato (printed on 4 1/2 sheets) to just under 3 soldi for a text combining the regola and donato.\

column1: All of this is strong evidence to support your claim of the continuing market for very conservative grammars well into the seventeenth century. \
** I would like to know why such grammars (as well as thin devotionals and slight works of hagiography) were sold and priced by the dozen. Anyone have any ideas about this?`
column4: `Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.30; InfoPath.1)`
column9: \N
`Fascinating. On-demand custom printing was not invented in the 1990s. In fact
column10: there will be a curve away from customizability as industrialization increases: the page makeup processes get more specialized
column11: presses become larger and faster
column12: and the distance from man to work increases. Now we have a curve back toward the personalization. But the system is so complex now that teachers still can't customize very well. What most teachers do for customization is photocopying.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X Mach-O; en-US; rv:1.8.1.20) Gecko/20081217 Firefox/2.0.0.20`

column9: `Paul
column10: I've been trying to sort out my frustrations about CommentPress. (There's also a competing product called Diigo that I was comparing a couple of months ago.) I think the problem lies not necessarily in the products themselves
column11: but possibly in the fact that works like yours are really already so practically comprehensive and complete that it seems almost a little late for individuals to interact with them.\

column1: If I were to get into this book (actually
column2: I can't wait to delve into the stuff on Erasmus!)
column3: I would need to set aside a significant amount of time -- at my desktop computer. But the product is so well constructed already that it actually merits being locked up and printed so that I can read it in a comfortable chair! I also find myself looking for structure
column6: and being disappointed.\

column1: I don't know if it's my old-fashioned "book" mind that craves the staticity and controlled nature of a printed and bound product (would a younger
column2: more postmodern reader prefer this format?) or if there is something objectively qualitative about a "ludic reading" experience (cf. Sven Birkerts) that calls for being away from the depths of the machine and precludes too much interaction.\

column1: Every discussion like this first calls to mind talmudist concentric marginalia and then the joyous "conversation" of scribbling notes in the margins of our own books. Maybe I just need to find more quiet time and space to be able to read these works carefully. I just went through the Rime of the Ancient Mariner online and I was fidgeting for half of it!`
column4: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.0; en-US; rv:1.8.1.20) Gecko/20081217 Firefox/2.0.0.20`

column9: `Reading this chapter again
column10: I am struck by the breadth of the vernacular reading curriculum. You do a great job of highlighting the considerable variety of texts (commercial/arithmetic
column11: musical
column12: how-to
column13: religious
column14: etc.) available to readers.  I am thinking you could (should!) add a section here
column15: something like "Sanctity in the Classroom." Religious educators such as Carlo Borromeo and Silvio Antoniano (in Milan) considered saint's lives to be important aids in moral instruction in both the catechism and vernacular schools. (see Turchini
column16: 1996). Numerous examples of such inexpensive texts (octavos
column17: 8-32 pp.) survive in Italian libraries. A sustained and extensive study of these booklets could yield interesting information about ownership
column23: `Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 5.1; .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.30; InfoPath.1)`

column9: `Thanks for this note
column10: Kev. There is certainly more work to do on "santini" and other pious booklets in the classroom. They straddle the boundary between what is usually thought of as "just" popular reading and instructional materials properly speaking (i.e. without entertainment or private reading value.)   As you say
column11: it would require examination of many copies to find those that clearly were used in schools.`
column14: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.7) Gecko/2009021910 Firefox/3.0.7`

column9: `The idea of "retailing commonplace thoughts" gives a whole new slant to the notion of "intellectual property
column10: since things bought and sold (even ineffable things) do amount to property. (Indeed, when such things go into print, they cease being ineffable.) What's interesting in this Renaissance context, though, is that private ownership of the property is not prized. Commonplaces are common" property whose value lies precisely in their commonness
column11: and the student/teacher/orator establishes his (or her) worth by demonstrating command of the common stock of wisdom (which might be "ownership" of a different sort). This whole attitude toward a commonly-held "intellectual property" obviously speaks to a different conception of selfhood in the Renaissance
column12: to different conceptions of ownership (one wonders how this might be reflected in legal documents)
column13: and (obviously) to different conceptions of the author/artist. I think the whole notion of the wholesaling/retailing of classical culture is very fruitful and provocative.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.7) Gecko/2009021910 Firefox/3.0.7`

column9: `Perhaps this has been changed since Diana Robin's comment
column10: but there is a "Next" link at the bottom of each section.  Scrolling to the bottom of the page leads to "Next: 0.02 Regionalism" allowing for the sort of linear continuity Diana seems to be seeking.  Perhaps this is slightly less intuitive since it appears after the footnotes (if one skips the footnotes this feature may be missed).  \

column1: Along a similar line
column2: I think it would be useful to link the footnotes in the text to the footnotes on the bottom of the page.  The hyperlinking of footnotes from citation to entry seems to be a fairly accepted convention at this point in electronic scholarly publishing.  This works best when one can return to the original place in the text by hitting the browser's back button (i.e. rather than having this return to the top of the page and having to work your way down again).  A pop-up window for footnotes is another potential solution.  In this scenario the reader can simply exit out of the pop-up and continue reading.`
column5: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.4; en-US; rv:1.9.0.7) Gecko/2009021906 Firefox/3.0.7`
column10: \N

column9: `Although the material covered in this paragraph is not integral to the overall argument here
column10: it probably needs to be reexamined nevertheless. I do not know the work of Baldsuhn (whose name seems to be misspelled in note 91)
column11: but most scholars understand Avianus to have been part of the Sex Auctores
column12: the curricular compilation popular in the eleventh and twelfth centuries. The Auctores octo
column13: mentioned here
column14: largely displaced the Sex Auctores in the thriteenth century and remained popular for centuries
column15: appearing in at least 50 printings in five countries before 1500; its fable collection is the one commonly attributed to Gualterus Anglicus
column16: whose introductory epistle
column17: written in the voice of the emperor Romulus
column19: not Avianus. I have seen many
column20: many printed versions of the Auctores octo
column21: and they all include this collection
column22: not the one attributed to Avianus. See Ronald E. Pepin's translation of the Auctores octo for further information.`
column25: `Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 7.0; Windows NT 6.0; WOW64; SLCC1; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506; Media Center PC 5.0; .NET CLR 3.5.21022)`

column9: `Your discussion of emblems is fascinating.  You introduce
column10: elucidate
column11: and contextualize the genre (and its evolution) wonderfully; I've never read anything like it before.\

column1: I have been fascinated by the evolution of the title page
column2: especially those that take the form of imaginary architectural spaces or cabinets of wonders that graphically attempting to represent or summarize a book's contents. I find what you have here immensely helpful. I'm thinking of Hobbes's Leviathan (http://www.library.usyd.edu.au/libraries/rare/modernity/images/hobbes2-1.jpg) or of Tycho Brahe's Mural Quadrant (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mauerquadrant.jpg). \

column1: It seems increasingly clear to me
column2: that these two works referenced above from the 17th and late 16th centuries represent a further evolution of the same sort of verbal / visual interplay you describe here
column3: whereas the designers attempt to render the whole of the text into the title page's picture plane.  \

column1: This leads me back to an earlier thought about this section on emblems.  Initially
column2: I wasn't convinced that your earlier description of "Emblem as Machine" (7.03) analogy made sense or
column4: I felt I was missing something.  As I got to thinking about the title page of Hobbes
column5: I recollected that Hobbes begins his Leviathan with a series of interrelated metaphors linking together God and nature; man
column6: machines ("engines"/"automata" in his words) and the higher form
column7: (as he sees it) art.  This leading to the visual metaphor depicted on his title page
column8: whereas the Monarch is the brain (or reason) operating the cyborg "this artificial man" (part man / part machine in Hobbes's complex metaphor) whose body is composed of the Monarch's subjects but described with mechanical language (rather than biological
column9: for example).   \

column1: Hobbes's nested and mixed metaphors are followed by a discussion of reading books vs. reading men vs. "reading thyself".  He then returns to his earlier cyborg Monarch metaphor.  When the Monarch is reading himself
column2: he reads all of mankind.  \

column1: Hobbes creates a riddle-like metaphor-laden passage
column2: which seems like an attempt to summarize the entirety of his book
column3: very much like the model you describe here of emblems with their accompanying poem.  With all of his mixed and/or nested metaphors it seems possible that his use of mechanical language also makes a connection between the play between emblem and text.  Or
column5: he seems to suggest that the text animates the emblem (this being the age of print
column6: this animation plays out in our minds).  The accompanying text provides the necessary code for how the emblem is to function (a code that wouldn't make sense on its own
column7: or would at least remain incomplete
column8: without the presence of the emblem itself).  \

column1: You discuss the role of medieval mnemonics as providing a model for the visual spaces of printed texts.  Even in the Hobbes's (or Brahe's) texts we can see the spatial or room metaphor of the classic medieval mnemonics continue (whereas related information is stored spatially in particular rooms).  The emblem seems to take this mnemonic out of the imagination onto the page
column2: where it evolves overtime
column3: still serving its mnemonic function but put to ever expanding uses.  \

column1: I apologize for this overlong (rambling) comment
column2: but I am still left wondering about your use of the term "machine."  By my count (and electronic texts make this easy!) you only use the phrase machine twice
column3: once in the section "Emblem as Machine" (7.03) (and only in the very beginning of this section) and then again once more in section 7.15.  \

column1: In what sense are emblems machines?  Perhaps this could use some more explaining.  I think you are onto something but your use of the phrase still isn't clear too me.  I think part of the difficulty maybe that it is a means of explaining the almost entirely unexplainable functioning across images and texts in a dynamic way.  (This seems to be the reason Hobbes utilizes the language of machines.)  \
These two OED definitions seem to be approaching what you mean:\
A material structure designed for a specific purpose, and related uses (def. II
column2: first used in late 16th century) and "An apparatus constructed to perform a task or for some other purpose" (def. IV

column1: I get why Hobbes
column2: in his time
column3: would look to the machine as a metaphor for animating his image via his text.  This is of his time.  Your discussing works predating Hobbes
column4: and I'm not sure if this "animating" concept I described above is what you are getting at.  It is a metaphor
column5: but I still feel like I'm missing something with how it is used here.  (And this could just be me
column6: because I haven't had time to deeply read what you have here--which is one of the clearest and best discussions of emblems I've seen.)`
column9: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.4; en-US; rv:1.9.0.7) Gecko/2009021906 Firefox/3.0.7`

column9: `This approach almost seems a commonplace in printed instruction books of the 16th century: "brief & easy
column10: and most useful and necessary" pop up again and again in writing manual titles.`
column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X 10.4; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032608 Firefox/3.0.8`

column9: `With handwriting
column10: vernacular seems to have been the norm from the very beginning. I know of only one writing manual in the 16th century with instructions in Latin: Mercator's "Literarum latinarum" of 1541
column11: although many writing manuals & copybooks included passages in Latin. This was due to a convention of writing certain languages in certain hands which
column12: in turn probably produced more work for writing teachers.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X 10.4; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032608 Firefox/3.0.8`

column9: `You might want to add Giovambattista Palatino's "Libro nuove d'imparare a scrivere tute sorte lettere" (Rome
column10: 1540) to this category. In it
column11: Palatino includes both an author's portrait on the title page and an emblem on the last page. The emblem of a moth in a candle flame with a motto taken from Petrarch: "Et so ben ch'io vo dietro a quel che m'arde" does not seem to relate to the book but perhaps the author's personality.`
column14: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; PPC Mac OS X 10.4; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032608 Firefox/3.0.8`

column9: `Alas
column10: I'm also a bit of an old-fashioned book fiend
column11: although the idea of a book on a blog -- a scholarly work that truly invites conversation -- is marvellous. While I agree that it's quite hard to read a scholarly text like this on a computer screen generally (eye strain
column12: internet issues
column13: clunky computer
column14: etc)
column15: I think the text might be easier to read if it were possible to spread it out across the screen in two broad columns (like the "book" reading function in MS Word)
column16: rather than having all of the text squashed to one side while the comments and the contents fields occupy two-thirds of the screen. I'm not suggesting that comments and contents fields disappear -- it's lovely to be able to see them alongside the text -- but perhaps the contents at least could be arranged horizontally at the top of the screen? Just an idea. I was also wondering if there's a way to flag or annotate pieces of text for my own personal use to come back to next time I log in to carry on reading -- ? Ironically enough
column17: I do feel strangely "lost" in the text -- despite the helpfully descriptive contents
column18: I really miss being able to flip through the pages to get a better idea. Perhaps it just takes a little more getting used to (I've only been navigating the site for about a week).`

`86`,`1`,`MQuinlan`,`mcgrathvi@aol.com`,`http://`,`71.239.76.150`,`2009-04-05 13:49:53`,`2009-04-05 18:49:53`,`I really enjoyed this book!  Many things I didn't know, several good leads for furthering my research, and it's always fascinating to see that textbook companies and the individuals that run them are following centuries-old patterns.  In my field (visual arts) there has often been criticism of government censorship of the arts.  At least as heavy a censorship, although much more subtly imposed, has been the bottom line of textbook publishing-- what plates cost, which images are already licensed to profitable companies-- all of this has much to do with what is easy or difficult to teach, and therefore what is taught. The internet is changing this somewhat, as it now is for book publishing in general.  Go Gehl!`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032609 Firefox/3.0.8`,``,`0`,`22`,`0`,\N

column12: King of the Jews" (from the gospel of Matthew

column14: O blood of the living God. May you
column15: who

column9: `Re: 2.11 visual example & 0.08 visual example:\

column1: New images at 2.11 seem but typical little boy pictures with totally innocent yet the typical delusions of grandeur. There is not much more than that. The availability of the writing surface seemed to be irresistible to the youngster for his own purposes and there are not enough meaningful scribbles for my taste.\
Contrast 2.11 with the magnificent singleton 0.08
column2: which seems somehow much more deliberate and from a more earnest or studious school boy. A creation. The boxes and lists of numbers/letters decry (or disguise) the one/two innocent little boy scribbles of dangling paraphernalia. An entire blank stimulated a real image to my eye and I find it much more interesting. \

column9: `Thanks for this comparison to the page at 0.08
column10: Susan. They do represent two kinds of final effect
column11: in that this one is partial and largely done by a single reader
column12: while the page at 0.08 is completely covered by marks made by at least three childish readers across a period of time we cannot determine. I will add a few notes there
column13: just to make that point clearer to other readers.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032609 Firefox/3.0.8`

column9: `Susan: Your notes at 2.11 suggest that you are loving this piece as a composition by a single child reader covering a temptingly empty page. In fact there are at least three hands here
column10: probably more. What shows up as a sort of smudge toward the top is probably the earliest mark
column11: an ownership mark by a youth named Liberio. Most if not all the boxes contain an anagram poem
column12: probably repeated by the same reader over and over. I would guess he is also responsible for the two roughly drawn penises
column13: because the ink is very similar. The long
column14: loose lines in greyish ink quoting a bit of doggerel in Italian
column15: "Chi vuol saver..." are by yet another reader. And the marks in reddish brown ink --including a comic profile head-- are surely yet another young owner. The all-over effect is
column16: therefore
column18: not the work of a single scribbler.`
column21: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032609 Firefox/3.0.8`

column9: `One example of a souvenir calligraphic manuscript copybook produced for the tourist trade is the Bernardino Cataneo Manuscript (Houghton MS Typ 246) acquired from the scribe by "Signor Odoardo Ralyg Gentilhuomo Inglese" in 1545. Cataneo
column10: who did not publish any known writing book
column11: was a maestro di scrivere at the University at Siena. For further info
column12: see "An Italic Copybook: The Cataneo Manuscript" by Stephen Harvard (N.Y.: Taplinger

`119`,`142`,`Hannah_Zdansky`,`hzdansky@nd.edu`,``,`66.254.239.239`,`2009-04-22 19:25:52`,`2009-04-23 00:25:52`,`With regard to the identification of the Cato of the Disticha Catonis, we are told in the tradition of the Accessus ad auctores that, â€œDuo Catones erant Romae, Censorinus Cato et Uticensis Cato,â€ that is, Marcus Porcius Cato (the Elder), whom you cite, and Marcus Porcius Cato â€œUticensisâ€ (the Younger) (d. 46 BCE). Perhaps you should mention both and possible conflations? The attributions may be incorrect, but the fact that most people believed in the authorship is important when it comes to studying the reception of the text in the Middle Ages and beyond.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032609 Firefox/3.0.8`,``,`0`,`30`,`1`,\N
`120`,`142`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`24.148.49.21`,`2009-04-23 06:43:32`,`2009-04-23 11:43:32`,`Good point. In fact confidence in the attribution was the single largest factor in the centuries-long prestige of this text. Below we will see several humanists who argued, even when they recognized it could not have been authored by an historical Cato, that the work was wise enough to merit his name. This kind of word-playful manner of writing is one of the lessons the text had for new readers. Every Latin text, the teachers were saying, even the most elementary, should engender literary wit along with the wisdom.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.8) Gecko/2009032609 Firefox/3.0.8`,``,`119`,`2`,`1`,\N

Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.2`,`2009-04-30 10:43:40`,`2009-04-30 15:43:40`,`I have done some re-checking of my sources here and find that Edward's correction is accurate as far as the Auctores octo goes. Baldzuhn as cited remarks some 60 (mostly Northern European) manuscripts that combined Avianus with the Distichs of Cato. But the print collection, Auctores octo, always includes the Aesopian fables in the verse translation of Walter the Englishman, not Avianus.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.10) Gecko/2009042316 Firefox/3.0.10`,``,`82`,`2`,`2`,\N
`153`,`173`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`24.148.49.21`,`2009-05-08 21:51:28`,`2009-05-09 02:51:28`,`Thanks, Dan, here as elsewhere for your elegant re-translation. I see how the Catones can be read of the two admirable individuals. As Hannah Zdansky noted in her remark at 2.02 above, medieval and humanist authors knew both figures and had a good sense of the reputation of the clan. But as you will have noticed throughout my writing, I am fascinated by the way these personal names are transferred to the books themselves. Do you think Bebel might have intended a double meaning, so that these Catones" are books
column13: constructed in parallel to "the book called Cato" as well as contrasted with the two human Catos? Perhaps he would have used "a quibus" instead of "in quibus" if he meant it to be read the way I translated it?`

column9: `Traditionalizing

column9: `Dan Sheerin
column10: in a note that appears by mistake on the previous section
column11: remarks of this translation
column12: "utriusque virtutis] We need more context to figure out to what utriusque virtutis
column13: â€œof each virtue/of both virtues
column14: â€ refers.\

column1: Unfortunately
column2: as often happens in early modern books
column3: such phrases appear pretty much without context. The Latin in note 95 is the entire text of the rubric which precedes the Cato in this edition of the Donat and which separates the Pseudo-Donatus rules from the precepts of Pseudo Cato. The sense might be understood as instruction in  liberal arts and also every appropriate virtue. The rubricator seems to be struggling to get both grammatical and moral instruction into his brief advertisement for the book.`

column9: `Do you reckon this emblem has any relation to the ancient Eye of Providence
column10: which I recall being associated with the Trinity (usually inside a triangle)
column11: once it was used in the Middle Ages?`
column14: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.9.1) Gecko/20090624 Firefox/3.5 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`

column9: `Alciati imagined the form as a brief poem with motto that assumed a mental picture created in the first instance by the author and re-created for the sake of the puzzle by the reader. All part of the erudite game. Within just a few years
column10: however
column11: publishers got hold of the form and printed pictures
column12: thereafter altering the dynamic. Scholarly authors continued to compose emblems without pictures
column13: but the standard form from the 1530s onward is the one we recognize today
column14: the picture puzzle.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.11) Gecko/2009060215 Firefox/3.0.11`

column9: `When Max Barry read this chapter

column9: `And so here we see the merging of a traditional patronage system with the newer concerns of commerce
column10: do we not?  And the snake emblem is the product of this shotgun marriage.`
column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-GB; rv:1.9.1) Gecko/20090624 Firefox/3.5 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`

column9: `Yes
column10: the two applications are different but overlapping. The emblem form stimulated several different uses beyond Alciati's original one of learned entertainment
column11: but the puzzle is at the core of all of them. The reader may enjoy solving the puzzle
column12: may learn skills from the process in or outside a classroom
column13: or may use the emblem for private meditation. Some collections had one or the other of these for a starting point
column14: but most emblems are suitable for all three uses.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.11) Gecko/2009060215 Firefox/3.0.11`

column9: `Any known connection of Hunger to the Jesuits?`

column9: `I'm a bit unclear how to reconcile the phrase "vehicle of meditative poetics and a machine for contemplation of the divine" with the commonplace ethical truisms the emblems so frequently illustrate or embody.`

column9: `This seems most convincing: "creating collegiality among an elite group of students."  A lot of education does this
column10: as we all know.  The emblems then become part of a socio-economic project to reinforce useful class distinctions.`

column9: `The emblem makes a particularly good opportunity to cross over between commercial and non-commercial culture
column10: insofar as it allows businessmen to display their intellectual bona fides. In this particular case
column11: Bernardo Giunta never received court subsidies in the measure he hoped for
column12: but he did get a noble title out of the deal.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.11) Gecko/2009060215 Firefox/3.0.11`

column9: `It would have to have been post hoc factum

column9: `Then I must have misunderstood.  Hunger died in 1555.  The first Jesuit college

column9: `Sorry

column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.11) Gecko/2009060215 Firefox/3.0.11`

column9: `Right. In fact
column10: Italian academic emblems are usually of the non-commonplace sort. They strive for as little-obvious a referential frame as possible. In this way
column11: they attempt to create or sustain elite
column12: exclusive communities --by contrast to most school-oriented or public-consumption emblems which aimed to create broader communities of readers who bought into humanist political commonplaces.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.11) Gecko/2009060215 Firefox/3.0.11`

column9: `I went back this morning to the most recent work I know on Hunger
column10: just a few pages really in Koehler. He gives a brief bio of Hunger
column11: who matriculated at Ingolstadt and taught there later in life after a peripatetic youth. It seems unlikely that he knew nothing at all of the early Jesuits
column12: but there is also no indication that he was influenced by them. If anything
column13: the influence would have been in the other direction
column14: since our best guess as to the origin of Jesuit emblem-making (which flourished mostly after 1580) is that it started in Germany under the influence of German humanist schools like those Hunger envisions.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.11) Gecko/2009060215 Firefox/3.0.11`

Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`24.148.49.21`,`2009-08-06 20:27:47`,`2009-08-07 01:27:47`,`In addition to the sources cited in note 61, there is now a new essay on Petrarch's Itinerarium by Theodore J. Cachey, in Petrarch, A Critical Guide to the Complete Works (University of Chicago Press, 2009), 229-241. Cachey makes the important point that for Petrarch, the imaginary, uneven, and highly episodic journey of the Itinerarium was a reflection of the author's literary wanderings. At exactly a period of relative stability in his domestic life, Petrarch restlessly travelled back and forth from one work-in-progress to another.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.13) Gecko/2009073022 Firefox/3.0.13`,``,`0`,`2`,`3`,\N `206`,`1`,`John Vincler`,`johnvincler@gmail.com`,`http://`,`24.166.35.58`,`2009-09-05 23:56:43`,`2009-09-06 04:56:43`,`There is something wonderful about

column3: and then we can see CommentPress providing a newer digital model at work here in your text.  (The â€œcomic stripâ€ provided in this same illustration
column4: sets up another very different but parallel example.)  This reminds me once again that â€œprint cultureâ€ is never fully coherent
column5: it can only point us towards the profound role technology plays in the process of interpreting old texts by adapting old or inventing new strategies for creating new texts. This process is never as neat and as linear as it may at first seem. And certainly not every innovation offers an improvement.  \

`Thanks
column10: John
column11: for drawing the analogy between the Renaissance commented page and the kind of dialogue we are attempting here at Humanism For Sale. In fact
column12: the interplay of base text
column13: commentary by several critics across nine or ten centuries
column14: and illustrations in the new technology of print is exactly the kind of cumulative
column15: collaborative scholarship we are hoping to promote. It already exists informally within circles of colleagues and friends
column16: but putting it online changes the dynamic for the better and offers a (perhaps utopian) opportunity to enlarge the conversation still further. \

column1: I do think
column2: however
column3: that it is worth trying to figure out what is NOT staying the same. For me
column4: the highly structured Renaissance page offers a hierarchy of authority that is not congenial today. Exactly because there are specialists out there who know more about a specific text than I do
column5: my research report is open to question and correction. And because a number of artists and designers have made notes too
column6: I have acquired new eyes for the beauty or interest of things that looked ordinary or even banal before.\

column1: Again
column2: these comment fields let me add notes on things I am observing anew. For example
column3: in this page the type in this detail from a title page seems to sag. This irregular effect sometimes actually occurs in early printing
column4: but here it is an illusion caused by the way the photo was cropped to show just the text. In the fuller image given at 0.07
column5: you can make out clearly that it is caused by the fact that the page would not lay flat for the photographer. For both conservation and aesthetic reasons
column6: I prefer to have the bowing of the page shown
column7: but just here it may cause some viewers to judge the facts of the printing wrongly.`

`"Working class" is --both for Grendler and to me-- a modern term of analysis (inevitably understood in Marxist or post-Marxist terms
column10: though neither of us is a Marxist). It does not have an exact equivalent in the sixteenth century
column11: but it helps us understand the elitism of the Latin school curriculum. Italians of the period had a clear sense that the full-dress Latin course was most appropriate for boys of the political classes. Correspondingly
column12: they knew that most boys and women did not have access to this course except through the charity or good will of some educators. The interesting thing about the prefaces to the self-study books that appear in the 1520s is that their authors both recognize this opportunity gap and set out to remedy it by selling their new books to this under-served group. This kind of sales pitch is perennial for self-help books --look at Amazon any day!-- but it is still a novelty at this period.\

column1: Your reference to Marxism
column2: Eric
column3: raises a slightly different question too
column5: does the awareness of class differences necessarily imply tension or conflict between the two groups? Although many of the voices we can hear in the period deny such tension --they tend to see class differences as inevitable and to respond in terms of the obligation to Christian charity-- there is also plenty of explicit evidence that the rulers felt there was social tension and that a degree of social mobility through education was one way of relieving it.`
column8: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.14) Gecko/2009082707 Firefox/3.0.14`
column13: \N

column9: `You quote Tagliente as saying "poor boys" would receive the same opportunities as "rich one[s]." Is this equivocal to what you term "working class men" at the end of the paragraph? I'm not sure I understand the usage of the term "working class" as it applies to Renaissance Italy; does it have the same Marxist connotation as in twentieth-century historiography?`

column9: `So as I understand this
column10: Grasso and Giraldi were conversing in print in the vernacular Italian
column11: which supposes a broad audience. Yet their subject was a series of works written in Latin
column12: and the appropriateness of those works in the curricula of contemporary schools
column13: which would have had a much narrower audience. At first
column14: this makes little sense
column15: for why would you write to a broader audience that may not care about the issue at hand. But if the focus of Grasso (and Giraldi) was not the content of the argument
column16: but the debate itself
column17: this use of the vernacular discussing Terence is understandable.`
column20: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.14) Gecko/2009082707 Firefox/3.0.14 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`

column9: `Yes. You are right to point to the oddity (from our point of view) in attacking or defending Terence
column10: studied always in Latin
column11: in the vernacular. Keep in mind
column12: however
column13: that this was part of a much larger debate
column14: in which the Giraldi family as a whole was deeply involved
column15: over the nature of poetry. This debate went on largely in Italian
column16: but necessarily involved the value of classical poetic models
column17: Terence being a standard author. So
column19: Terence is not the real subject
column20: though we risk anachronism if we discount how passionate sixteenth-century readers could get about beloved classical authors.`
column23: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.14) Gecko/2009082707 Firefox/3.0.14`

column9: `"The preface goes on to claim preeminence in commerce for Florence..."\

column4: did the 'origin' of the text become more important than its author

column9: `It's not quite common
column10: but not entirely unique to this book either. Most ambitious printers were looking for audiences beyond their own cities
column11: and in the case of school books in Latin even international audiences. There were local and regional markets
column12: however
column13: which are described in summary fashion in section 0.02
column14: and some teachers seem to have published primarily for their own students. One example is described in section 7.10.`

column9: `Christopher S. Celenza's 2004 work "The Lost Italian Renaissance" urges scholars to study the Latin writings of Renaissance Italians for a fuller understanding of the contested subject. He also stresses the dire need
column10: especially in the United States
column11: for more translations of Latin Renaissance texts. "Humanism for Sale" seems to fit in quite nicely with what Celenza wants
column12: and where he thinks the interdisciplinary field of "Renaissance Studies" should go in the new millenium. How do you
column13: as the scholar
column14: feel about this assessment?`

column9: `"general tendency throughout our period to see careful record keeping (and good
column10: clear handwriting too) as part of honest commercial practice"\

column1: It's intriguing that the emphasis in the sixteenth century was on legible handwriting
column2: whereas today we identify some prestigious occupations by the very opposite.  The illegibility of doctors' hands are certainly a commonplace in the modern world
column3: and yet doctors are not thereby considered dishonest.  An interesting transition...`
column6: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`
column11: \N

column9: `I tried posting this comment in the body of the text
column10: but it was not working. This is probably a mistake on my end. What strikes me about "Humanism for Sale" is that the scholarship seems to speak to the concerns of Christopher S. Celenza. His 2004 work "The Lost Italian Renaissance" expresses the dire need for scholars to study the Latin texts of Renaissance authors for a broader understanding of the time period. He also urges researchers to take the time for the thankless duty of translating these texts to encourage further graduate study
column11: especially in the United States. "Humanism for Sale
column12:
though focusing on a specific set of writings, is a step in the direction Celenza envisions for Renaissance Studies. `227`,`398`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`24.148.49.21`,`2009-09-21 20:03:03`,`2009-09-22 01:03:03`,`The interesting thing about the passage you cite in Celenza's book (which I think overall is brilliant, by the way) is that he seems to have decided there is no chance we can train American scholars to read Latin well. So Americans need translations, while we can assume the philological training in Italy and Germany will continue to flourish, and those scholarly publics will not need translations. No doubt this opinion of Celenza's derives from the practical experience of his own teaching. I guess, since I live in a research library world, I am more optimistic about Americans reading Latin. Still, these Latin works (not necessarily the schoolbooks I spend time with, but certainly the dialogues and poetry and treatises that constitute the original works of humanists) deserve to be better known.  Fortunately, we have good translations (with Latin on facing pages) coming out regularly now from the Harvard I Tatti series, one of the most exciting initiatives or recent years

To punt the question back to you, Mike: Do you think we need more and better Latin training, or more and better translations? You (not I) are the future of Renaissance studies, so it is really the students in your class who must answer this question.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`,``,`221`,`2`,`4`,\N
`228`,`388`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`24.148.49.21`,`2009-09-21 20:09:33`,`2009-09-22 01:09:33`,`Good question, Maureen. Maybe my section title is a little misleading. In fact many Jesuit emblems are about devotion to the Blessed Virgin, but do not include images of the Virgin herself. This is part of the general strategy of emblematics, to create puzzle-pictures, in which the subject is referred to only indirectly. \
\
Alas, the Partenoapean emblem book is very rare and we do not have a copy at the Newberry from which I could give you a concrete example of how the emblems really look. I have used it only on microfilm, and that on loan from a scholar here in Chicago.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`,``,`0`,`2`,`0`,\N
`229`,`26`,`laur_bee77`,`laur_bee77@yahoo.com`,``,`71.234.29.136`,`2009-09-21 22:05:54`,`2009-09-22 03:05:54`,`It would seem to me that prior to the invention of mechanical printing presses the distribution of texts would vary from one another greatly, which would influence the overall learning of material in the texts by students.  The ability to mechanically print texts led to standardized testing and teaching to the masses, removing the regionalizing.  I think your point that the classroom affords us a window on groups of readers" is still true and although the delivery of texts have become more standardized and consistent the view is still not clear.  You state that as students grow intellectually as readers they "employ these skills with increasing degrees of individualism"
column13: Educators are faced with a decreased level of overall understanding and comprehension of material in and out of the classrooms by the students who stuggle to grow individually in the face of standardized testing and mass production of classroom textbooks.  I wonder if it was more beneficial to have students learn from regional texts created by their teachers.`
column16: `Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 6.0; WOW64; Trident/4.0; SLCC1; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; Media Center PC 5.0; .NET CLR 3.5.21022; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; InfoPath.2; .NET CLR 3.0.30729)`

column9: `I tried to respond to this paragraph and after hitting "add comment" it disappeared so I will attempt again.  I wonder if it was more beneficial to students in the Renaissance to recieve their education from teachers and regionalized texts rather than from mass printed materials.  I agree that the classroom "affords us a window on groups of readers
column10: but does not always give us a clear view."  This statement could not be truer as we face standardized testing efforts based on mass produced generalized text books which are used in classrooms.  Students struggle to comprehend material and 'keep up' yet don't actually learn and it is evident on their tests and in their interactions with one another in and out of the classroom.  It does not really surprise me that students do not choose to expand their horizons by exploring older considerably more difficult texts of old.`

column9: `". . . introduced himself as a Sienese schoolmaster who had taught arithmetic all over Italy and Sicily . . ."\

column1: I find the differing marketing strategies  between Latin grammars
column2: which were based largely on the legitimacy of the authors
column3: and these math and other 'self-help' texts fascinating.  In the previous section I wondered if particular cities could be the basis for legitimacy.  Here I see that Sfortunati cast himself as an experienced teacher and a native speaker of Tuscan
column4: highlighting the importance of vernacular.  I get the sense that there is much less argument between competitors over content in the case of math than over method--whereas content was a major concern for those marketing/selling Latin grammar (even as method was also a key issue).`

column12: \N

column9: `You are certainly right that there was relatively little to differentiate basic math content from one book to another. But the teachers did find themselves involved with the different commercial traditions of towns where they taught. Venice and Florence were great rivals
column10: but every small town had its own set of weights and measures
column11: its own currency
column12: etc. So there is plenty of room to sell different styles and methods of teaching.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.14) Gecko/2009082707 Firefox/3.0.14`

column9: `Well
column10: I'm all for studying historical texts. But one of the basic principles is to look at them carefully on their own terms and avoid anachronisms at all cost. Generalizing is always a peril
column11: and anachonism is among the problems we risk when we generalize. With reference to your specific observation
column12: the peril is in overstating the identity of printed books. Standardization as we know it is hard to impose on early printed books. Certainly they are more standardized than manuscripts
column13: but by our measures they vary immensely from copy to copy both in production terms and in patterns of use.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.0.14) Gecko/2009082707 Firefox/3.0.14`

column9: `In Chapter 5
column10: you discuss conservativism with regard to Jesuit education. You say â€œ Educational conservatism sometimes consists of such inertia. Teachers and (just as often) parents want the children of today to learn the same lessons in the same ways that their elders had. Attachments to textbooks
column11: especially books that were widely memorized
column12: often took this form -- affection reinforced by inertia.â€(5.07). This
column13: and the sections that followed raised some questions for me. Is there any indication that parents challenged the centralization of Education that was part of the Jesuit program? The chapter emphasizes this combination of issues:  localism
column14: conservativism and education
column15: which is interesting because my immediate assumption is that they indicate a demand for cultural autonomy (rather than just the cultural sensitivity that was the cause of localized printing). Would you say that people in general were reacting to the centralization of education in a way that advocated local control?`

column9: `It would be great to be able to draw this broad a conclusion
column10: but I don't think we have the evidence to support it one way or the other. Parents' voices are hard to find in the surviving sources; they tended to vote their preferences merely by sending their children to one school or another. In section 5.13-16
column11: I try to explicate what little evidence the textbooks themselves offer --merely to the point that there was some demand for alternative schools. Sales records and shop inventories offer a few more clues.\

column1: There is one other potential source. To some degree
column2: we can imagine that the laymen in city councils
column3: who felt that they should be overseeing education in their towns
column5: when there are recorded city council debates
column6: that is a potential source.  A good study of one such town is by Christopher Carlsmith on Bergamo
column7: forthcoming from University of Toronto press.`

column9: `I find it quite fascinating that textbook markets were generally local and regional in early modern Italy
column10: perhaps because I'm used to thinking of textbooks being standardized and marketed nationally.  Are there any examples
column11: though
column12: of a regional market being influenced by an international one
column13: or vice versa?  I have the publishing market connections between Venice and London in mind
column14: so I'm curious about the ways
column15: if any
column16: local textbooks markets may have been influenced by international ones for other types of books.`

`252`,`335`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`24.148.49.21`,`2009-09-26 17:13:16`,`2009-09-26 22:13:16`,`It may well be a coincidence, but there is one concrete link. Clement was well known as a patron of the arts, and Arrighi, then in Rome and in the papal service, specifically compares the skills of a calligrapher to those of a musician. I am reasonably sure he had the numerous musicians of the papal chapel, and papal patronage for new music, in mind when he decided to go to press.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`,``,`251`,`2`,`5`,\N

column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3`

column9: `You are right to note that I use it fairly loosely and inclusively. In general I take the whole range from 1450 to 1650
column10: as noted at the very start (section 0.01
column11: with specific reference in footnote 2 to John Marino's and Chris Celenza's discussions of periodization). This makes sense in publishing terms since it includes everyone in print from Gutenberg forward
column12: and the fuzzy upward border allows us to include many highly conservative publications that appeared well into the seventeenth century but embodying much earlier educational practice.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`

column9: `The issue of teachers publishing their own books certainly has resonance today. Some scholars are pilloried (in my view
column10: rightly so) for requiring students to purchase privately published course readers at exorbitant prices. On the other hand
column11: I myself did a primary source reader for Italian Renaissance courses (Blackwell
column12: 2004) because I got so frustrated with finding one that suited my own teaching needs. I have made precious little money off it
column13: but that was not the reason I published it.\

column1: Humanism for Sale is surely parallel to numerous other self-published (non-text-) books
column2: some of which have had impressive circulation over time. Having just taught it to a class of ten graduate students
column3: I can say that it provoked lively discussion on numerous levels
column4: including of course the contrast between printed texts and online texts. At the risk of belaboring the obvious
column5: I was struck by how easy it was for the students to gain access to this text: whereas several other excellent monographs from the past decade now cost well over $100 and
column6: if not purchased
column7: must be obtained via interlibrary loan
column8: "Humanism for Sale" popped right up on students' computer screens. Perhaps
column9: as "Google Books" becomes more comprehensive (see Tony Grafton's recent essay on the subject
column10: online in the New Yorker
column11: I believe)
column12: the contrast in access will be less stark; but for now
column13: surely
column14: it is highly significant. This mode of publication fills a need that I suspect is rapidly increasing.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.5; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3`

column9: `This book is wonderfully rich throughout. I like having the images right with the text

column1: Sometimes I lost the thread from section to section when reading chapters on-screen. When I printed out some chapters in toto and read them the old-fashioned way

column1: Is there any way to make the footnote markers "live" so that one can click on them to gain access and return to the same place in the text? I ended up consulting far fewer of them as I read than I normally would do. Also
column2: since the citations in the notes are overwhelmingly in short form
column3: a live link to the bibliography would help immensely. Eventually I figured out I just needed to download the .pdf of the bibliography and keep it open on the side of the screen.\

column1: Thanks
column2: Paul
column3: for putting your book online! This is a great resource to which I'll return again and again.`

column9: `The first Giunti device (70 x 28 mm)
column10: two putti holding cornucopias in one hand and with the other hand holding the fleur-de-lis above
column11: appears in the 1512/13 edition of the Opera of Lucius Apuleius.  It then appeared often and was the only device by the press used until 1517.  It contains no motto.\

column1: Zappella
column2: fig. 645; Kristeller
column6: Printers' marks (London

column1: The second device has two putti standing on a chest
column2: each holding a cornucopia and together supporting overhead an elaborate fleur-de-lis.  On the front of the chest are the initials â€˜F.G.' The whole enclosed in a folded ribbon border (135 x 94 mm).  The same border appears also in the 1506 Giunti edition of Dante.  This
column4: first appears in the 1517 Orationes of Aristides
column5: the Vitae parallelae of Plutarch and the Icones of Philostratus.  Davies says that Kristeller shows three devices with a similar border: nos. 21
column7: 182.  This is the largest and most important of the early Giunti devices (Kristeller 46) and was last used in the 1527 Xenophon.  Davies
column11: fig. 66 and Zappella
column12: Le marche dei tipografi e degli editori italiani del Cinquecento fig. 646.\

column1: The third and fourth devices
column2: both appear in the 1517 Valerius Maximus
column4: the other at the colophon.  These are the only two devices
column5: of the more than 40 used by the Giunti in Florence up to 1625
column6: to use the motto in question.  Zappella
column7: figs. 649 and 647.  Fig. 649 last appeared in 1588 in Dottrina Christiana breve per insegnare in pochi giorni by Diego de Ledesma which is the second part of the work Della scelta d'orazioni divotissime by.Girolamo (in religion Silvano) Razzi;  Fig. 647 made its final appearance in 1617 at the end of the text of Achilles Tatius' Dell'amore di Clitofonte
column8: e Leucippe.  I find it remarkable how long some of the devices were used--or revived after several decades.  I have not used a loupe on the later appearances
column9: but to the naked eye they seem to be identical.\

column1: As to your correct remark about the fleur-de-lis and its relation to the Giunti and the city
column2: I might add one little-known note.  The lily is still visible
column3: carved  on the stone lintel of their onetime store in the via Proconsolo
column4: opposite the Badia in Florence.  It is now a store selling briefcases and suitcases and the sweet people running the store knew their place had a long history but were unaware that it was for a century the bookstore of Florence's most famous publishers.  Sadly
column5: even the city of Florence has done nothing
column6: not even a plaque
column7: to record the fact.  I believe it was Douglas McMurtrie who pointed out that the first printer's devices were closely related to the signs over their shops.  And one small correction--Bernardo was the second generation printer
column8: not third.  I am still puzzled by the remark made a century ago by Fumagalli to the effect that Bernardo was made a "comte palatin."  I know of no archival evidence for this
column9: and Fumagalli cited none.  On the face of it
column10: it seems highly unlikely.`
column13: `Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; GTB6; .NET CLR 1.1.4322)`

column9: `You put your finger on the exact point of my "ad man" metaphor
column10: Jane
column11: and its limitations too. Although advertising strategies are clear in the rhetoric of this and many other Erasmian prefaces
column12: it is not always entirely clear whom he was addressing. Certainly he wrote to and  for his own circle of humanist friends
column13: but that was preaching to the choir. Effective advertising must also reach a wider audience of book buyers. In this case we have mostly the success of the edition itself (and its frequent reprinting with this exact same preface) as evidence for the wider audience of the advert.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.3) Gecko/20090824 Firefox/3.5.3 (.NET CLR 3.5.30729)`

It might be something you could keep an eye out for in the kinds of inquisitorial court documents you see in our own research.(I am always surprised where everyday things like textbooks turn up in documents.) But your suggestion that these were slight and unimportant books is also to the point. The sixteenth-century ones are not as concerned with magic as the medieval ones

column9: `It should be noted that the tradition of illustrating the classics
column10: both in original-lanugage editions and in translation
column11: remained much stronger in Northern Europe than in Italy through most of the early modern period. Italian humanists in this regard were more conservative and text-oriented than comparable humanists north of the Alps. A good example of Northern humanist love of illustration is Sebastian Brant (1457-1521)
column12: on whose career in print
column13: see especially the contributions of Vera Sack in <em>Sebastien Brant

column9: `This image shows one of the internal title pages to the Opera omnia of Mancinelli published at Venice in 1518. Each fascicle contained one or two short works and they could be purchased separately
column10: so a title page like this was an advertisement for the work in this pamphlet. The first paragraph here dedicates the work to a prominent citizen of Mancinelli's home town
column11: and to his son
column12: one of Mancinelli's students. The six-line poem that follows is addressed to the student and tells him what this textbook will help him learn.`

Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.2`,`2011-01-24 14:44:23`,`2011-01-24 19:44:23`,`Further on Maturanzio, see now the contribution of Erminia Irace and Maria Alessandra Panzanelli Fratoni in Maestri, insegnanti e libri a Perugia, Milano, Skira, 2009, pp. 138-143, including illustrations of books with his notes an commentaries.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.9.2.13) Gecko/20101203 Firefox/3.6.13 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729)`,``,`0`,`2`,`5`,\N `311`,`357`,`yossimaurey`,`yossimaurey@gmail.com`,``,`193.52.208.233`,`2011-02-10 09:13:52`,`2011-02-10 14:13:52`,`It is interesting to note that with the advent of music printing in the early 16th century, many of what we can call interpretive actions" (embellishments
column24: which were frequently dependent on a direct contact between musicians (including teacher and pupil)
column25: could now be mastered also by those who had little contact with the performing scene.  Just like with the invention of musical notation
column26: the distance between composer and performer/interpreter received another push.`
column29: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; en-US; rv:1.9.2.3) Gecko/20100401 Firefox/3.6.3`

column9: `Another significant use for Latin vocabulary studies was for Italian composition
column10: since it was widely held that imitation of the classics would enrich the potential of Italian to achieve its full literary potential. A good example of a small manual with this aim is Girolamo Labella's Regola della lingua tosca dell'ortographia volgare et Latina (Venice
column11: Rampazotto
column12: 1570) which claims to be based on the personal teachings of grammarian Girolamo Cafaro. My thanks to Giles Mandlebrote for examining a copy of this rare work for me at Kings College
column13: London.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.16) Gecko/20101130 Firefox/3.5.16 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `Pescetti also authored a small Latin textbook
column10: which I have never seen: <em>Tabulae ad grammaticam celeriter et feliciter perdiscendum utilissimae
column11: in quibus uno velut intuiti
column12: quicquid ad hanc artem pertinet
column13: inspicere licet (Verona
column14: Tamo
column15: 1600). This title implies that it took the form of a summary aimed at beginners. At this date it was clearly intended as part of Pescetti's campaign against the Alvares grammar.`
column18: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.16) Gecko/20101130 Firefox/3.5.16 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column11: Merlo

column15: Olschki

column9: `This condemnation of Erasmus' Cato took place in Lucca in the context of the struggle of the city fathers there to avoid the imposition of a local tribunal of the Roman Inquisition. In addition to the article by Adorni-Braccesi cited in note 6 below
column10: see also her more recent book-length study of Erasmanism
column11: Calvinism
column12: and the Inquisition at Lucca: Simonetta Adorni-Braccesi

column19: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.18) Gecko/20110614 Firefox/3.6.18 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `There is some disagreement among scholars about when and how the Donat was used. My own thinking is as remarked in 2.01
column10: that some time was first spent in learning the alphabet and a few prayers
column11: memorizing first and then "reading" in the sense of recognizing texts already familiar. A sharp student could get through this quickly
column12: but some took a fair amount of time at it. When ready they would be set to memorizing the Donat
column13: but all the discursive sources agree that these donatistae were still rank beginners.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.1.19) Gecko/20110420 Firefox/3.5.19 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `Further on Paleario as an educational reformer
column10: see Simonetta Adorni-Braccesi
column11: Una citta\` infetta
column12: Florence: Olschki
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.18) Gecko/20110614 Firefox/3.6.18 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `By "instrumentalizing" here I mean the (relatively modern) notion that language study is primarily an auxiliary or prerequisite to the serious study of other
column10: more substantial disciplines
column11: not a normalizing or moralizing discipline in itself. The Jesuits were pioneers in this view of language study. For a broad view of the history of Latin study
column12: see especially Francois Waquet's Latin or the Empire of the Sign.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.18) Gecko/20110614 Firefox/3.6.18 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `The wording and the persistence of these claims suggest strongly that Fabrini himself composed these title page statements. As he added to the apparatus in subsequent editions
column10: each new 'feature' was described in an additional title page blurb.`
column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.21) Gecko/20110830 Firefox/3.6.21 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `Scholars attribute the first edition to Vincenzo Valgrisi
column10: a Venetian printer responsible for several later editions with Fabrini's revisions. Note
column11: however
column12: that the title page shown here does not name a printer. None is named elsewhere in the book either
column13: suggesting that this first edition was subsidized by the author or his friends and patrons and was not a commercial product. Compare this purely typographic  title page
column14: which though wordy is relatively uncluttered
column15: with that of the 1558 Valgrisi edition below where the same advertising prose must be compacted to make way for the prominent commercial printer's mark of Valgrisi.`
column18: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.21) Gecko/20110830 Firefox/3.6.21 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `This detail shows the passage quoted in the next paragraph. If you click on it
column10: you will see the entire title page of this edition by the highly successful Sessa-family publishing firm at Venice. (In this case the imprint is "heirs of Marchio Sessa.") As in the Valgrisi title page above
column11: the advertising prose is kept in tiny type so as to provide room for the firm's trademark. When rival firm's took on Fabrini's text
column12: they typically varied the wording and order of the advertising prose but reproduced the list of features on offer to prove that their edition was just as good as others on the market.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.21) Gecko/20110830 Firefox/3.6.21 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

`336`,`302`,`vhorw`,`veronikahorwath@yahoo.com`,``,`50.28.169.155`,`2011-09-19 22:42:41`,`2011-09-20 03:42:41`,`Pescettiâ€™s attacks, however petty and quixotic, against the educational presence of the Jesuits in Verona and his alternative suggestions for an ambitious program of compulsory and universal schooling organized by the city fathers highlight an important area of tension that Iâ€™m surprised did not surface more frequently and virulently in counter-reformation Italy.  Even given the relative stalling of the process of state consolidation in the peninsula during this time, why did municipal and territorial rulers not try to establish a monopoly on education over competing claims of religious entities more frequently? In the German states, the unequivocal settlement of the Peace of Augsburg did not stop wrangling over education between state entities and competing claims even when everyone was in the same confessional camp.  Were these battles less relevant in Italy because schooling remained comparatively more limited to upper social strata rather than becoming a tool for religious mobilization?`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/4.0; SLCC2; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET CLR 3.0.30729; Media Center PC 6.0; HPNTDF; InfoPath.3; .NET4.0C)`,``,`0`,`1734`,`1`,\N
`337`,`110`,`Janice Gunther`,`janice.gunther@uconn.edu`,``,`137.99.94.222`,`2011-09-20 08:10:39`,`2011-09-20 13:10:39`,`I can understand why teachers would want editions of Terence with several commentaries and an extensive critical apparatus.  But would young students also own copies of Terence with at least some apparatus, or would they use copies without much/any apparatus and make annotations themselves?  In reading about all these editions, I keep comparing them to the appearance of the chaste manuscript version of chapter 1.05.  But even in manuscript, you mentioned that there were plenty of commentaries and annotations.  Do we find manuscript copies of Terence where the commentaries crowd out the text, or were they normally copied separately, and perhaps bound together?  You also mentioned that the de Gouveia commentary was printed separately- how frequently were commentaries printed separately (and perhaps bound with another copy of Terence)?  Do you think that teachers became increasingly reliant on commentaries in their teaching, compared with the 15th century, or did they just have more choices?  Thanks!`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/535.1 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/14.0.835.163 Safari/535.1`,``,`0`,`1724`,`1`,\N
`338`,`276`,`eddie.guimont`,`edward.guimont@uconn.edu`,``,`72.221.96.103`,`2011-09-20 12:39:36`,`2011-09-20 17:39:36`,`Italians may have been isolated from New World discoveries, although given that Italian navigators and innovations were vital to the initial imperial adventures of those other states, I wonder if there was an initial interest that died off once Spain, et al., developed independence from that Italian aid. But at the same time, Italy was where refugees from Byzantium traveled, and had more direct contact with the Arab and Turkish worlds - through the attempted Ottoman invasions, trade contacts, and as a site to prepare for Christian counter-attacks on the Muslim world - than many of those same imperial powers who were focused on the New World. So I wonder, is there any evidence that while Spanish, Dutch., etc., humanists were more receptive to the geographic and naturalistic discoveries of the New World, Italian humanists may have still been receptive to discoveries and contact in the other direction, ie, with the Eastern world? Or by the 15th/16th centuries, had the knowledge of the Muslim world been largely diffused throughout Christendom already?`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.0; rv:6.0.2) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/6.0.2`,``,`0`,`1723`,`1`,\N
`339`,`276`,`eddie.guimont`,`edward.guimont@uconn.edu`,``,`72.221.96.103`,`2011-09-20 12:51:17`,`2011-09-20 17:51:17`,`I tried posting this before, but my comment got eaten, so let's try this again...\
\
I wonder if the fact that the earliest voyages to the New World, if not done by Italian states still were done with Italian navigators and innovations, allowed for an early interest in the New World discoveries by Italian humanists, only dying out after the imperial powers developed independence from Italian aid. Also, Italy was the place of refuge for those escaping the fall of Byzantium, as well as a main center of contact â€“ through attempted invasions, trade, and attempts at counter-attack â€“ with the Arab/Ottoman world, having much closer contact than the imperial powers like Spain, Portugal, etc., did. Did this result in Italian humanists drawing more inspiration on the geographic/naturalistic discoveries of the East, even if they ignored the discoveries coming in from the other direction? Or was the knowledge of the Muslim/Eastern world so diffused through Europe at this time that it would have had little impact on Italian humanists specifically?`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.0; rv:6.0.2) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/6.0.2`,``,`0`,`1723`,`1`,\N
`340`,`302`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,`http://`,`205.178.2.148`,`2011-09-20 16:14:23`,`2011-09-20 21:14:23`,`I think you have put our finger on one of the important factors that limited state intervention in Italy. Throughout the period, there was a great deal of debate as to whether it was a positive social good to educate non-elite citizens, and there was a strong party of opinion against it. Local churches in Italy came down strongly in favor of catechism education (Doctrina Christiana --see below, sections 6.11 and 6.12), involving reading and sometimes writing, but there was no impulse comparable to that in N. Europe to go much beyond the elementary skills needed for devotion.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.22) Gecko/20110902 Firefox/3.6.22 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`,``,`0`,`5`,`1`,\N
`341`,`110`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,`http://`,`205.178.2.148`,`2011-09-20 16:23:28`,`2011-09-20 21:23:28`,`Hi, Janice. The hyper-extended commentaries we see in the fifteenth and sixteenth centuries are definitely a creation of the market for print. Some heavily commented texts existed in the Middle Ages, but they were reference copies owned by teachers, scholars, or libraries and usually confected exclusively for local use. Students most often took down the text and whatever notes they needed by dictation. The separate commentaries by humanists were intended for advanced study; I have never seen one bound with a base text, but that may just be because I have not been looking for them. As to the degree of dependence on commentaries, that is hard to say. Certainly there were more choices, and I suspect teachers by the early sixteenth century would not have been comfortable teaching without a commentary to hand. But what we know of teaching in the late Middle Ages and early Renaissance suggests that was always true.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.22) Gecko/20110902 Firefox/3.6.22 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`,``,`0`,`5`,`1`,\N
`342`,`235`,`howardsend`,`wiedenheft.elizabeth@gmail.com`,``,`24.62.86.54`,`2011-09-20 16:23:32`,`2011-09-20 21:23:32`,`We have already observed Mancinelli's growing preoccupation with correction and enlargement
column14: which he seemed to feel was a normal process of reprinting."  It seems unusual to me to have such a need for correction in reprinted texts.  Presumably
column15: Mancinelli felt this to be normal because of his experiences correcting manuscripts
column16: and in his own role as editor and commentator on the works of other
column19: I begin to wonder about the need for what seems to me to be an excessive amount of corrections and commentaries by publishers in the printed works of Mancinelli.  Is this attitude towards printed grammar books and their constant need for correction an offshoot of manuscript culture
column22: more needed?  Or were these corrections and comments simply a way of advertising reprinted editions of the texts in order to make more money?`

column9: `You guessed it! The orb surmounted by a single or double cross is a commonplace mark in Italian presses of the first century and it often bears the initials of the printer or publisher. Olschki imitated the style and since they have the same initials as Soardi
column10: the resemblance is striking. I don't remember exactly what the O stands in Soardi's mark
column11: but you can look it up in G. Zappella's guide to Italian printer's marks
column12: published in 1986 --but not by Olschki.`

column9: `It is rather surprising for exactly the reason you hint at. Hebrew
column10: although a prestigious form of erudition
column11: was only very rarely studied and it would be very odd indeed to try to learn it from self-help books like the Mercuries (at least that is what they purport to be). In the context of either Latin or Italian studies
column12: the educational orthodoxies of the day suggested that the two languages could be used to improve facility and promote elegance of expression. I strongly suspect that Schoppe is making a show of his own learning in the quadrilingual books
column13: and that the "utility" of the Greek and Hebrew was to the same purpose
column14: to allow readers to stud their compositions with short phrases or proverbial sayings in those languages without really mastering them.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.22) Gecko/20110902 Firefox/3.6.22 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `I am interested in your statement "One thing humanists all over Europe in the fifteenth and sixteenth century shared was a pugnacious willingness to argue that derived from scholastic models. Petrarch made many innovations in humanist thought
column10: among them introducing a sustained polemic against the scholastics. In so doing he also imported into humanism the quarrelsomeness of the universities
column11: where disputation pro and contra was a permanent fixture."  I had not before connected scholastic disputation with the development of humanist dialogues and invective
column12: and you note that the latter was based on classical models. Could you provide more detail about how you see the relationship between scholastic disputation and the development of humanist dialogue and invective?`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/535.1 (KHTML
column16: like Gecko) Chrome/14.0.835.186 Safari/535.1`

column9: `Kristeller's 1974 essays and Rummel's study
column10: cited in the notes
column11: are still the best treatments I know on this subject. It's not one that I can claim to have done original research on. Rereading my own prose at this point
column12: I can see that I may seem to have intended to suggest a direct
column13: derivative relationship of genre between humanist invective and scholastic disputation. I really meant to say instead that the habit of antagonism typical of scholastic debate was still so much a part of scholarly life in the early Renaissance that it fed naturally into humanist forms. When dealing as I do in this book with the prefaces and other paratexts of published textbooks
column14: it is striking how frequently authors refer to polemical attacks -- often ones that do not survive or cannot easily be found in the record-- that were violent and personal enough to merit replies in print. In the case of famous figures like Erasmus
column15: we have a record of a great deal of the back and forth. For textbook authors (like Mancinelli to whom I refer here) we will probably never know who or how influential his critics were. We know only that he felt it necessary to take them on in second and subsequent editions of his textbooks
column16: in letters that became a permanent part of these textbooks as they were printed and reprinted for fifty years and more.`
column19: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.22) Gecko/20110902 Firefox/3.6.22 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `Very interesting! It seems like aspects of this continue today. In the trend of making texts that were in much older styles

column9: `It's intriguing to think that a whole slew of textbooks could have existed that we simply don't know about. It's interesting to wonder where all these resources could have gone

column9: `As I go on to describe below
column10: especially in chapter 5
column11: both the content and the style of presentation were sometimes deliberately archaic. It is not exactly like buying antiques today
column12: however
column13: since the products were intended for immediate practical use. Not even like a modern printer opting for old-fashioned wooden type --that is practical
column14: but not offered as the ideal model for modern printing.`

column9: `You are pointing to a commonplace in textbook history
column10: that these books were literally used to pieces. But I also think we overstress this point too much. We still have a chance to find more examples.  Just in the last ten years or so
column11: copies of editions we did not know about (or did not know survived) have turned up
column12: because librarians are cataloging online and their records show up internationally to be recognized by scholars. And we are far from having full cataloging still for many European libraries
column13: especially those in small towns or private institutions.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1`

column9: `It's interesting that spreading the word about different school books played such a big role in this history. How did one advertise to large groups of teachers and students in the middle ages? I suppose that's where the "celebrity" teachers come in; if they advocate for a certain author or book
column10: then that book or person's reputation would leap upwards. Does there still exist records or stories of how a particular book became so well known and widely used? Or do we only know which books were used based on what still exists today?`
