column9: `Good point
column10: Liam. What I wanted to convey here is that what we now think of as mainstream Christianity is a highly rhetorical
column11: language-centered faith
column12: but that medieval Christianity --in the absence of widespread literacy
column13: remember-- was strongly visual and oral. One of the lasting effects of humanism was to reclaim the rhetorical tradition of classical culture and make it over into a central fact of Christianity. This could only happen because humanist rhetorical ideas were adopted and made universal through wider literacy and through the medium of commercial print.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.23) Gecko/20110920 Firefox/3.6.23 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `There is an enormous literature and much debate on this question of how illustration was done. In textbooks specifically (and this cannot be generalized to all fields)
column10: the tendency is for the author of the text to specify the diagrams and illustrations required to the printer and the printer would then hire an artist to realize them. For manuscripts these artists were often part of a workshop team that confected the books to order. For printed books
column11: the tendency was for a wood engraver to work from a pattern provided either by the author or by an artist. But typically in print there is an attempt to keep the illustrations closely related to the texts.`
column14: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.23) Gecko/20110920 Firefox/3.6.23 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `We really don't have too many clear
column10: direct sources to tell us how the compositions of students were done
column11: but sometimes notes of the sort survive as scrap paper. Well into the 17th century
column12: however
column13: people used wax tablets for various kinds of note taking
column14: and that is probably how these exercises were most often performed. Paraphrase as a formal exercise always means rewording; it is a way to imagine ideas anew and to learn what kinds of expression work best.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.23) Gecko/20110920 Firefox/3.6.23 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `All of the typographical and layout devices you mention
column10: Miles
column11: originated in the manuscript period
column12: but of course
column13: in single manuscripts reproduced individually. They became much more common in the first age of print both because there were many more copies mad at once
column14: but also because printers copied (and teachers began more and more often to demand) things like this that made it easier to use the textbooks.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.23) Gecko/20110920 Firefox/3.6.23 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `Copyright as we know it
column10: to protect the author
column11: is really an 18th-century development. Before that there were various kinds of registrations and privileges that protected the publishers
column12: who were assumed to have made an investment worth protecting commercially. A good intro to the whole issue is Elizabeth Armstrong's book
column13: Before Copyright (Cambridge U. Press
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 6.0; en-US; rv:1.9.2.23) Gecko/20110920 Firefox/3.6.23 ( .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `Yes

column9: `Right! It is always a little hard for us to place a price on morality

column1: I am aware that
column2: during the Middle Ages and a good part of the Renaissance

column5: and gentleness were often looked upon as deviants
column6: whores
column7: or worse.  How have you seen this dichotomy played out in the emblems
column9: and engravings of the period?  What effects do you think these representations of women had in the lives of the men and few women who were able to access books?\

column1: What Thomas Laquer has called â€œthe One-Sex Modelâ€ was still being taught during this period.  I have seen several illustrations of this model in medical textbooks from the time
column2: and I am curious to know if you have seen examples in non-medical books for students of other disciplines
column3: and also in books of literature and/or poetry.   I agree that people of lower classes and women in general would have been ignorant of how their bodies and their genders were being defined
column4: but how aware of the One-Sex construction of the human body were people who could access education?  Is there any evidence to suggest that anyone was aware or suspected that sex and thus gender were/are social constructions
column5: and that these constructions serve not only to materialize the body
column6: but also to form our conceptions of â€œnatureâ€ itself

column9: `All of Alciati's original emblems were composed without pictures. He invented the form as a literary one where the picture was supposed to be imagined by the reader of the poem. Once the reader had imagined the image
column10: then he would re-read and understand the poem more fully. These original emblems were designed for manuscript circulation. The new emblems Alciati added for this later
column11: larger collection
column12: however
column13: were composed after the first set had been published with images made up for the printed book by artists not working directly with Alciati; so we must imagine that he has already re-conceptualized the literary form he invented only a few years earlier and was now probably working with an artist to create emblems with both pictures and poems. This is an unusual moment in literary and media history. We can not only witness the invention of a new genre
column14: but also watch how it was appropriated by new writers
column15: and then watch the inventor respond to the changes wrought by others on his invention. We see this happening online everyday but it was also an exciting event for sixteenth-century people
column16: to watch the media change before their very eyes.`

column9: `The notion of "emblematic thinking" is intriguing
column10: in so far as how it is related to metaphor and analogy (or allegory/parable)
column11: which definitely serve to teach or communicate messages more effectively and
column12: perhaps
column13: affectingly as well.  I am curious as to the extent of the "universalness" of this type of thinking
column14: and specifically of its application.  Were there many amateurs creating their own emblems?  How many children learning this thinking and "devising" of emblems apply their knowledge and in how many related ways outside of merely creating more emblem books
column15: and were they exposed at higher levels of education as well or only as a member of the general public?  Also
column16: how cooperative versus authoritative was the writer-artist production of emblems
column17: and out of curiosity were any writers also artists?`

column9: `The pedagogical use of emblems for women and children is interesting.  Were these emblems ever disseminated (or re-purposed) with vernacular mottos/poems in woodcuts catering to a more rural audience?  Or did these remain more or less exclusive to the urban bourgeoisie and landed aristocrats?`
column12: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1) AppleWebKit/535.2 (KHTML
column13: like Gecko) Chrome/15.0.874.121 Safari/535.2`

column9: `After not only encouraging "activist" thinking but also translating to regional vernaculars
column10: to what extent did these expand the open-mind syndrome of readers experiencing the importance of personal opinion
column11: interpretation
column12: and perhaps then critical analysis of systems beyond that of the emblem?  Or is it just that the emblems really were providing affective lessons of newly revisited morals that effectively left the reader with a new sense of reverence for the system as it was?  Mostly
column13: I am curious as to whether there were any popular exceptions?`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1`

column9: `"They were moral acts...":  At what point might we see that "puzzling something out" gains a high degree of social status
column10: especially in terms of morals?  Business-folk
column11: in one line of rhetoric
column12: are seen
column13: for example
column14: today as being de facto morally superior
column15: one could argue (as George Lakoff has)
column16: because they have figured out some special problems that others simply haven't.  It seems clearly implied
column18: that the mere publishing of such texts containing moral lessons and then spurring on the "puzzling out" of such and maybe other lessons for the readership would be in itself a very moral act.  Did technical problem solving ever see its day in those earlier centuries as a moral venture?`

column9: `By chance
column10: could one already see (and is there any evidence in their notes or lectures or pedagogical outlines or sermons for) teachers themselves or preachers limiting the more open-ended emblematic puzzles in ways supportive of social conformity?  Again
column11: were there any exceptions we know of?`

column9: `This section answers my question on 7.02. And I think the idea Emblem books is very interesting. And I agree that it requires "an activist kind of reading that engaged the mind in problem solving". I remember

column9: `You're the second person to refer to the Simplicissimus Teutsch
column10: Ky. I will have to find some time today to look at it myself. In general
column11: there is plenty of irony in printer's marks as in emblems more generally (and it is rife in Renaissance literary culture as a whole)
column12: but I cannot offhand think of an example that deliberately mocks a denominational group. False marks --or none at all-- were
column13: however
column14: sometimes used on heterodox publications. As such they could be considered another kind of false imprint statement.`

column9: `Good question
column10: Ky
column11: in the sense that the existing literature does not address these issues at all well. Wooden printing blocks are very durable and many got re-purposed in later centuries
column12: in general for less and less pretentious kinds of book
column13: eventually finding their way into chapbooks of the most popular sort. Bbut I know of no study that tries to trace this reuse systematically
column14: and my impression is that emblem blocks were not resused this way very often.`

column9: `Since our principal evidence for emblems is the printed books
column10: we don't have a very clear sense of how widely the making of emblems was practiced by amateurs. School emblems (see below
column11: sections 7.11 and 7.15) often had student input
column12: but getting them into print obviously required participation from adults in school and printshop. The one area where we can see lots of amateur emblems is in the surviving manuscripts. There is a good 1997 bibliography of these by Sandra Sider (available on Google Books if your library doesn't have it)
column13: but it needs updating already.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.0; WOW64; rv:8.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/8.0`

column9: `You are right
column10: Chen
column11: that many commonplace things (among them coins
column12: paper money
column13: and all kinds of flags) are or were originally designed to be emblematic. We are not systematically taught to read them
column14: however
column15: so we often just don't see that dimension of them. These commonplace images frequently get parodies (think of all the dollar bill take-offs) and that makes us at least look a little more closely.`

column9: `The conventions of publishing in this period are pretty fixed --only one title page
column10: which is why it becomes a contested field. The solution when there was more than one party was often for the printer to put his mark at the end of the book
column11: ceding the title page to the more prestigious author
column12: academy
column13: or public institution. Toward the very end of the sixteenth century you have the phenomenon of the second title page --usually an elaborate
column14: engraved plate that was a good place for really extended emblem-making. This would be followed by a typographic title page with just the discursive information.`

column9: `Did the authors of a emblem ever provide a sort of "key interpretation" of their emblem?`
column12: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; rv:8.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/8.0`

Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.2`,`2011-11-28 11:13:22`,`2011-11-28 16:13:22`,`The essence of the emblem is that it is a puzzle, so in the first instance there is rarely a key or solution. Alciati originally didn't even give a picture, just the poerm. As the genre evolved, however, some of the more popular collections were issued in annotated editions where there would be a commentary on each emblem that would solve the puzzle or at least explicate the several dimensions of it.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1`,``,`431`,`2`,`4`,\N `434`,`365`,`Chen JS`,`jc6vd@mail.missouri.edu`,``,`161.130.188.41`,`2011-11-28 14:12:10`,`2011-11-28 19:12:10`,`In chapter 16 (16.18 and 16.19), some title pages of the music textbooks look similar to an emblem consisting of three parts. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.2`,`2011-11-28 17:09:23`,`2011-11-28 22:09:23`,`Yes, as you note, devices on title pages preceded the formal emblem. However, the two title pages you point to in the last chapter are different from each other, and might be worth looking back at, since they may explicate the form. The title page in 6.18 has a true emblem (pictorial object with motto --actually two mottoes-- that complement the picture without solving the puzzle). The title page in 6.19, by contrast, is a narrative scene, the Annunciation to the Virgin, without motto or any particular puzzle dimension.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:7.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/7.0.1`,``,`435`,`2`,`1`,\N `437`,`377`,`annirdmn`,`arhd7@mail.missouri.edu`,``,`50.81.143.115`,`2011-11-29 11:30:53`,`2011-11-29 16:30:53`,`I found it really interesting to read about how an imprint can actually be self-explaining, when we know the meaning and quality of it. \ \ It is also interesting how printers' marks are later being used as reputations or symbols and basically sell the book, because the symbol is right on the front on the title page. \ \ I feel like the reader has to sort out, whether the book is a shoddy book or a good book, or rely on other opinions, this is how culture changes.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; U; Intel Mac OS X 10.6; en-US; rv:1.9.2.24) Gecko/20111103 Firefox/3.6.24`,``,`0`,`1926`,`0`,\N `438`,`377`,`Paul F. column9: `Dear Paul Gehl
column10: I have a couple of questions: In this paragraph it is written that Tagliente's manual appeared in 1524
column12: within a year of one authored by Ludovico Arrighi (d. 1527). 1527 is three years later. I also have images of La Operina
column13: by Ludovico Arrighi
column14: dated 1522. Was Arrighi the first to publish a writing manual? Note 53
column15: in chapter 6.09
column16: does say that Arrighi's first book appeared before Tagliente's
column17: was that book La Operina? Thank you`

column9: `Thanks for your note
column10: Monica! Although many of the early writing books are dated
column11: there is some dispute as to their actual dates of publication. I based this very summary sentence and much of the rest of my account on A.S. Olsey's Scribes and Sources
column12: which suggests that the 1522 Operina of Arricghi was rushed into print in order to anticipate Tagliente's known plan to publish
column13: and that the actual date of its appearance was 1523
column14: not 1522. That would put it very close in date to Tagliente's 1524 book. It is certainly clear from the date on the 1522 Operina that Arrighi wanted us to believe that his book was first.`

column9: `This certainly highlights the difficulty of the perpetual problem of dating printed writing books. I think that the 1522 date in "La Operina" refers to when Arrighi originally prepared his manuscript. Not only does Osley date it later but so does Stanley Morison. In his "Early Italian Writing-Books
column10: edited by Nicolas Barker (1990), chapter 3 focuses on the publication date of La Operina." Morison/Barker suggest it was probably printed in the first half of 1524. As you know
column11: in 1525 the book's engraver
column12: Ugo da Carpi
column13: sued for the right to publish his edition. Morison/Barker raise the obvious question: if the book was published in 1522 why did Da Carpi wait 3 years to sue? They offer other substantial evidence as well.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:16.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/16.0`

Among the books sent from Valladolid (a major book entrepot) to Santiago (in much more provincial Galicia), there are six entries for Terence, including at least one used copy, two copies of a Spanish translation, and eight new copies of Latin editions in quarto and sextodecimo. See: Rojo Vegas, From Europe to Finisterre: A Caravan of Books to Galicia (1595)
column12: in Print Culture and Peripheries in Early Modern Europe, ed. by Benito Rial Costas (Leiden: Brill, 2013), pp. 381-401, at 391.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:17.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/17.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`2`,\N `459`,`221`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.148`,`2013-01-03 03:38:58`,`2013-01-03 08:38:58`,`Further on the distribution of Mancinelli's textbooks, see now my Advertising or Fama? It would be a way of making a personal mark like an authorâ€™s title page emblem, but also a memory techniqueâ€”a handwritten note beside an emblem might represent a larger idea or conclusion. This practice is so common in the present, I can hardly imagine reading a textbook without highlighting or writing questions and ideas in the margin. Were these books too valuable to be scribbled in? Or did the advent of printing and resulting ease of text production render them less precious? Or was the idea of writing in a book not so problematic in the first placeâ€”I remember learning that many surviving medieval personal books of devotion, painstakingly composed by scribes, are rife with the handwritten notes of their various owners. Iâ€™m curious how ideas of ownership and personalization played out in this new type of text.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8) AppleWebKit/537.22 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/25.0.1364.152 Safari/537.22`,``,`0`,`2162`,`4`,\N `486`,`390`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.2`,`2013-03-11 10:47:55`,`2013-03-11 15:47:55`,`Marginalia are common in medieval books and in printed books from the start. The notion that you should NOT write in a book is relatively modern. column9: `Typically the emblems are woodcut in the earliest examples and engraved in later ones. Woodcuts are printed in the same form as type; engravings have to be printed separately
column10: usually before the text

column9: `As is discussed in the chapter â€œHumanities in Crisisâ€ It is interesting that humanistsâ€™ own critical intellectual nature led to the demise of their monopoly on learning
column10: do you know of any educators who began as humanists and changed the type of teaching format they used because their critical education made them question some fundamental aspect of humanism? \

column2: and required â€œa century or more.â€ Since most of those interests in his manuscripts were educators I wonder who would actually undertake this task? Would it be educators themselves
column3: or would humanists collaborate with monks or another group in order to sort out the manuscripts?`
column6: `Mozilla/4.0 (compatible; MSIE 8.0; Windows NT 5.1; Trident/4.0; GTB7.4; (R1 1.5); .NET CLR 1.1.4322; .NET CLR 2.0.50727; .NET CLR 3.0.04506.30; .NET CLR 3.0.4506.2152; .NET CLR 3.5.30729; .NET4.0C)`

column9: `For Latin schoolbooks
column10: which is my primary subject in this section
column11: there are several terms (like "rudimenta
column12: which I mention here, or manuale") that should indicate elementary texts
column13: but they simply aren't used regularly
column14: especially early on. This specific kind of description of intended audience is usually included later on in the title or in a preface or introduction where it will specify "for boys" or "for young people." I discuss this further in chapter six

column9: `Actually
column10: early modern people saw books as instruments or tools and that meant they felt very free to mark them up --both for their personal use and for the use of other people who would use them. One by-product of the relative scarcity of books was that many individuals would often use a single book
column11: either together or across time. My personal favorites are brothers and sisters
column12: parents and children who put their names in a single books
column13: sometimes across several generations.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:19.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/19.0`

column9: `Interesting! I bet the the utilization of visual models in textbooks made them much easier to understand and aided many students who performed better with visual representations rather than just text.`
column12: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_6_8) AppleWebKit/537.22 (KHTML
column13: like Gecko) Chrome/25.0.1364.160 Safari/537.22`

column9: `Well
column10: in general before the twentieth century
column11: students were invited to conform to communitarian ideals
column12: just because notions of individual freedom were not so well developed then. But I bet if you look at your textbooks today --think back to high school-- you would find that you were more often being encouraged to "be good" than to do wholly original thinking.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:19.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/19.0`

column9: `You are pointing to something that educational reformers were campaigning for in exactly this period
column10: but it took a long time for visual learning to become a really widespread ideal. The popularity of emblems --which were not originally intended for young people-- probably helped promote this kind of thinking among educators.`
column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:19.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/19.0`

column9: `It seems as though the printer's emblem was a way in which to locate the work within geographical space. This makes me wonder
column10: how popular was it for printers to also reference their works temporally by also including a date of publication?`
column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_8_2) AppleWebKit/537.22 (KHTML
column14: like Gecko) Chrome/25.0.1364.160 Safari/537.22`

column9: `Interesting that you make this geographical leap
column10: Courtney. The printer's mark certainly identified his firm
column11: and usually printers had only one location
column12: but most of the marks do not have geographical references. They tend to be based on literary sources
column13: just as other emblems do. And some of them were deliberately international -- firms like the Giunta had branches in several cities in Italy
column14: Spain
column15: and France but they always used some form of a lily mark. As for dates
column16: they are rare in very early printed books but become pretty much universal by the end of the fifteenth century --except in exactly the case where the mark might be omitted
column17: when the printer did not want his work to be easily identified or traced.`

column9: `I am curious as to how the interpretation of emblems could be conceptually and morally restricted yet still imaginative. Could you clarify what this would mean? If the author inserts a text that already clearly delineates a certain moral significance to the emblem
column10: what kind of latitude does the reader still have in the interpretative process? If a specific meaning is intended
column11: what kind of variations in interpretation would have been â€œacceptable?â€`
column14: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.2; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.22 (KHTML
column15: like Gecko) Chrome/25.0.1364.152 Safari/537.22`

column9: `Good question
column10: Vivian. I am generalizing here
column11: so it may not be clear what the process of limiting meanings was. To understand how it happens
column12: you have to remember that the emblem is structured from the start as a puzzle. The texts do not explain the meaning(s) outright
column13: they only comment on the image and give clues to meaning(s)
column14: which are always potentially personal as well as comunitarian. That is
column15: the reader always has the ability to create her own meaning for the image or to suggest alternatives that may or may not have been in the mind of the author. The more text the author adds
column16: however
column17: the more clues the reader gets to move in one direction or another. To cite a trivial example
column19: if the author intimates that eagle in the image represents  dominance
column20: then it can only represent themes consistent with that
column21: not those that have to do with flight away from power. There is still room for interpretation by the reader
column22: but she is directed toward certain themes and not others.`

column9: `Itâ€™s interesting to see during the sixteenth and seventeenth centuries it was widespread practice to use images to add more layers of complexity
column10: even in every day settings. I was wondering
column11: how much difference in terms of obscurity/complexity would there be in an image that would be found in a textbook
column12: as compared to an image on a poster or storefront? Would a book image necessarily be much more intellectually demanding in nature? And how long did this practice of using â€œinventionalâ€ images in daily settings persist â€“ is this practice considered to still be around in the same form today?`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 9.0; Windows NT 6.2; WOW64; Trident/6.0; Touch; MAARJS)`

column9: `In very general terms
column10: basic textbooks are popularizations
column11: so the emblems there(like other things--tables
column12: charts
column13: etc.) tend to function like posters or other public art --explaining complex ideas in a simple way
column14: or at least at several levels
column15: one of which can be understood quickly and without reflection. Once emblems are compiled into books
column16: however
column17: they can afford to be more complex because the book form invites slower
column18: more thoughtful reading. As for today
column19: we have lost the emblem theory
column20: but designers of many things try to include several levels of meaning. The most obvious example is trademarks or logos --just think of the red-white-and-blue theme of many corporations. The name or image may not evoke patriotism but the designers try to stimulate it or just refer to it with that color scheme.`

column9: `Right
column10: Christina. We typically think of it as a usage in prayer books and liturgical books where it helps fairly sophisticated readers maneuver around complex texts. In schoolbooks it does that on a simpler level
column11: and also serves to make the book more attractive to new
column12: presumably inexpert readers.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:20.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/20.0`

column9: `This was interesting to learn about.  I love seeing the red and black print in the old books
column10: and thought it was always decoration.  So
column11: it is good to know that the red and black printing technique was used productively
column12: as well as for decoration.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.31 (KHTML
column16: like Gecko) Chrome/26.0.1410.64 Safari/537.31`

column9: `Would you expand on Aldo Manuzio's pedagogical motives regarding the graphics and design of his textbooks? Did he commission fonts designed to enhance readability and therefore marketability?`
column12: `Mozilla/5.0 (compatible; MSIE 10.0; Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; Trident/6.0; BOIE9;ENUS)`

column9: `Right
column10: Peter. We have this rather exaggerated opinion of the power and conformity of the Jesuit order that derives in part from the realities of Jesuit life codified in the seventeenth century and in part from a long Anglo-American political and historiographical tradition of distrust for the order. In the 1550s
column11: however
column12: the order was still new; it was composed of many dedicated and often brilliant men who knew St. Ignatius personally
column13: and who were quickly scattered to many parts of Europe. The later centralization was not yet in place. What fascinates me most about the Alvares grammar is that it was one of the first products in publishing history to gain anything like the popularity and widespread influence that even a routine Microsoft release gets today.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:21.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0`

column9: `I expand on Aldo as teacher in section 2.05
column10: paragraph 4 below
column11: where I give the specific example of how he used red and black to aid students in comprehension. Your question is a little broader than that
column12: Nancy
column13: in that you ask about type faces. In fact Aldo did commission several types for his press
column14: and it is usually said that the famous Aldine italic (there are examples in section 1.09 below) was invented for the sake of economy and legibility. But none of Aldus's faces was designed specifically for textbooks. The significance of his teaching career really lies in the fact that he could control the entire process --from authorship
column15: through design and printing
column16: to marketing.`

column9: `If I understand this correctly
column10: the emblem book was supplementary by default
column11: but it was also part of a dialogue between children's education and formalized education - which would seem to suggest that the material in each emblem book (varying
column12: as you say
column13: by region) would have a specific perspective or slant
column14: focusing on different aspects of education in a way that fit the expectations of education in that region? Or is that saying too much?`

column9: `Yes
column10: that's true. But the regional variations were even wider than just education. Keep in mind that most emblem books at most periods and in most places were not tied closely either to formal education or to schools. They were intended for personal reading
column11: meditation
column12: and enjoyment. They were most often connected to schools in Northern Europe
column13: especially in the Low Countries and Germany
column14: and the Jesuits (see section 13 below) particularly used them.`

column9: `It surprises me that the grammar books prior to Alvares were not more successful (Codret
column10: des Fruex
column11: de Ledesma) or long-lived. Regardless its flaws
column12: I would think almost any book with the full weight of the Jesuit order behind it could have had at least modest international success. I hate most Microsoft products
column13: but I still buy and use them.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:21.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0`

column9: `I find it surprising that Alvares' grammar was sent out for international review and it changes my perspective on the Jesuit schools. I always knew the Jesuits were influential and international
column10: but I had not thought much about the economic and educational enterprise behind their endeavors (social and religious enterprise for sure). When I think about sending books out for feedback
column11: collecting and analyzing that feedback
column12: and making decisions with that information
column13: I see that they are more than a collection of schools
column14: but a school systemâ€” perhaps not too unlike what we see today.`
column17: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:21.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0`

column9: `I like this idea of a 'school system' as an analogy for what the Jesuits were doing. They certainly set out in the Ratio Studiorum to create a system --one could correctly translate 'ratio' as 'system.' The source documents about the creation of the Ratio have all been published
column10: and they make for fascinating reading. I think the reports of the various committees
column11: quickly summarized in the next paragraph
column12: evidence a process that was for the period genuinely open. Above all the teachers seemed to feel that they needed some freedom to use whatever texts they had
column13: adapting them as necessary to the particular needs of their students locally.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:21.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0`

column9: `Looking at the title pages of the earlier works (Syntaxis
column10: De constructione octo partium orationis)
column11: the typographical hierarchy gives precedence to title. Later works (De institutione grammatica libri tres)
column12: reverse the design and give precedence to Avares' name as though it were the title. I imagine this was a deliberate marketing decision to lead with the author's name. It makes me think of those paperback novels you might see in line at the grocery store
column13: where the biggest type on the cover is the name of the author (e.g. Danielle Steel). You have to look closely to see the actual title. In cases like Steel
column14: no matter the title
column15: it's the author's name that sells. In the case of Alvares
column16: it is interesting to see that the book began to be called "Grammatica Emmanuelis
column17:
and was even titled as such in later editions. \
\
Before reading these chapters, I had always guessed that Avlares was your typical author-celebrity typeâ€” wanting to see his name in lights, so to speak. However, the descriptions of him wanting to pass a quiet career as a schoolteacher, his admonitions about boastfulness, and his modesty, make me think it was the Jesuit publishing enterprise that thought to build the Alvares brand the way it did.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:21.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0`,``,`0`,`2383`,`6`,\N
`505`,`288`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.148`,`2013-06-23 18:56:01`,`2013-06-23 23:56:01`,`Bingo! You are absolutely right, Peter, about the Jesuit marketing effort and branding --they phrased it in more traditional terms, promoting the use of a book by one of our own"-- but it is clearly an effort to create a book with a Jesuit identity. In later years it was used sometimes outside the Jesuit schools
column18: but even then it was identified with them and their particular theories of language education. The evolution of the "Grammatica Emmanuelis" label is a bit of a puzzle to me
column19: though it follows a pattern typical in the book trade. I suspect it started largely as a typographical convention
column21: if you are going to specify the author with both his name and surname
column22: "Emmanuelis" is going to take up nearly a line anyway
column23: so it becomes prominent visually more or less by default. When booksellers and buyers looked at the title page and compared it to others
column24: the most prominent word was the easiest shortcut with which to refer to to book
column25: and gradually this became the commonplace way to refer to it in a crowded market for Latin grammars.`

column9: `I imagine many examples of these texts also remain hidden in private collections or the uncataloged (or non-public) inventories of booksellers. Some records of these books do see the light of day briefly when they are recorded for sale online. Unfortunately
column10: many of the records do not persist on the internet like those of the libraries. I think it would be valuable to collect
column11: store
column12: and share these often fleeting descriptions (as imperfect as some may be) for the use of scholars and collectors alike. Oceans of potentially valuable information on books are appearing and disappearing on the internet every day.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10.7; rv:21.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/21.0`

column9: `This is true
column10: Peter
column11: though not entirely a new problem. Dealers' printed catalogs always included useful information (my files are filled with tear sheets or photocopies). Some libraries created indexes to this material
column12: and digitization has allowed for more and more of it to be stored and used. But you are really pointing to a different problem entirely
column13: the fragility of records that are created only on line. Capturing that information would alleviate one other problem
column14: the cases of very rare survivals that emerge on the market for a moment and then disappear back into private collections where they may remain hidden to interested scholars for a generation or longer.`

column9: `As the citations in note 2 here indicate

A good basic summary of the results of this research appears in an essay by Robert Black in the Short Oxford History of Italy volume entitled Italy in the Age of the Renaissance 1300-1550

`558`,`321`,`Peter K`,`pkilpe@comcast.net`,``,`73.213.118.19`,`2015-05-25 19:52:51`,`2015-05-26 00:52:51`,`It's interesting how you have put the non-Latin reader in the context of marketing books. As accessible as a vernacular textbook was, do you think there were still major economic hurdles that might have inhibited their commercial success? I can imagine large institutional buyers (or influencers) and the educated elite shunning the vernacular texts. I recently came across Edmund Reeve's An Introduction into the Greeke Tongue" (London: NP
column30: a early Greek grammar in English. The title page reads "Composed for their sakes which understand not Latine; and yet are desirous to have some competent knowledge in the originall sacred scripture." One would think that a basic Greek grammar in English might have a ready audience
column31: yet the book does not appear to have had much life beyond the first edition (a second issue including an an errata leaf was printed in 1657).\

column1: Another work that comes to mind is Elizabeth Elstobâ€™s â€œRudiments of Grammar for the English-Saxon Tongueâ€ (London: Printed by W. Bowyer
column2: 1715). The book is the first Anglo-Saxon grammar in English
column3: and Elstobâ€™s preface speaks to why she wrote it: "Considering the pleasure I myself had reaped from the knowledge I have gained from the original of our mother tongue
column4: and that others of my own sex
column5: might be capable of the same satisfaction: I resolv'd to give them the rudiments of that language in English dress.â€ This beautifully printed book
column6: with new Anglo-Saxon types created for the project
column7: was a commercial flop. It was ignored in favor of other works (in Latin) in use at the time. Like Reeveâ€™s grammar
column8: Elstobâ€™s book ended with the first edition.`
column11: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_9_5) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML
column12: like Gecko) Chrome/43.0.2357.65 Safari/537.36`

column9: `Thanks for these two examples
column10: Peter. I think they start to give an answer in their own words. Both of them offer personal histories--apparently pretty singular if not in fact entirely original-- for how difficult it was for the non-Latin literate to study ancient languages. Although both Reeve and Elstob saw immediately how it would help others to have an introductory text in English
column11: they did not recognize that their own experiences were so nearly unique that there was no built-in audience for their books. It is easy for us to underestimate the conservatism of educators in the early modern period. The institutional buyers all wanted textbooks that would fit the existing curriculum
column12: not entirely new ones. \

column1: Still
column2: your initial question about marketing rhetoric merits some further thought
column3: for at least Reeve and Elstob specifically devised addresses to non-Latin reading potential users. This practice of imagining a not-very-educated reader/user goes back at least to Tagliente
column4: and there are other examples later in this chapter too --see 6.17 on "poor churchfolk."\

column1: I'll hope to come back to this theme with further examples
column2: and maybe some more solutions too.`
column10: \N

column9: `Peter's 17th and 18th-century examples
column10: above
column11: make me think that a real desideratum would be to trace the trope of the non-Latin reader through book history over the long haul. Before printing (and therefore before the marketing impulse was strong)
column12: there is a regular distinction between those who read (Latin) and those who are illiterate. It appears especially in prefaces to translations of Latin works into vernaculars in the manuscript period
column13: where the reader is addressed sometimes fairly personally. It seems to me to take on new meaning in the "how-to" period we encounter several times in Humanism For Sale
column14: e.g. at 4.14 and 4.18 above
column15: and below at 6.11
column16: where it is clearly a marketing tool. The key period for this is the 1520s. \

column1: Perhaps putting a lot of examples like Peter's from a single large discipline or genre (his are language study works --grammars) would be an instructive data set.`

column9: `In saying that I have not seen annotated copies
column10: I was thinking of the kind of annotations that students make in textbooks. However
column11: a number of surviving copies of Alciati were used as autograph albums (the period term for such a book is album amicorum) by university students
column12: meaning that during their studies and travels

column9: `By contrast to this Italian reader's interest in philological errors (especially those of his countrymen)
column10: the reader (probably German) of a copy of the Art of Verse (Spauter 1512) now at the Newberry Library has marked up the preface with notes that mostly display interest in Spauter's rhetorical ability to skewer his adversaries with pointed insults. Treatises on verse were often marked up with indexes that helped their owners use vocabulary correctly and effectively in their own verse; this reader was clearly interested in prose rhetoric as well.`
column13: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:33.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/33.0`

column9: `Lazzari and Lozzi's argument offers a good example of the risks we run if we consider short literary forms like epigrams trivial
column10: occasional
column11: or frivolous works without useful value as historical evidence. True
column12: they are minor forms
column13: but especially in sizable collections like Mancinelli's they offer valuable biographical data and cultural context.`

column9: `I don't know why it occurs to me to reply only now (five years after Dan's thoughtful comment) -- maybe I am just being deliberate
column10: as admonished by the source texts here.  I think he is right in pointing to manners as the immediate dimension of morality that classroom subjects address. But I think that ancient
column11: medieval
column12: and Renaissance thinkers generally saw morality as a continuum that ran uninterruptedly from table manners to moral decision making. Moreover
column13: this continuum or spectrum of behaviors crossed through language learning
column14: thus the power of Latin study to inculcate good habits along the way and the importance of good manners of all sorts to the orderly learning of language.`

column9: `Thanks
column10: Diana. The only true wisdom resides in careful generalization. I tried to set the scene for this in the introduction (especially sections 0.3 to 0.6). To your specific point here
column11: however --yes
column12: it is important to stress both that textbooks offer only a limited view of pedagogy and that pedagogy is not the whole of humanism. I do belong to the school that sees humanism as first and foremost an educational reform movement and only secondarily a literary and philosophical one. But even beyond that difference of starting point
column13: I hope that Humanism For Sale has shown that one of the most important loci for understanding humanism and the humanists is in the defense of their educational program that printed textbooks embody.`
column16: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:41.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/41.0`

Donati describes this edition at p. 251, but does not remark the anomaly.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`7`,\N `580`,`211`,`cmoghadam`,`cpmyv6@mail.missouri.edu`,``,`162.104.213.12`,`2016-02-03 16:13:31`,`2016-02-03 22:13:31`,`I find this statement about the availability of tutoring positions and Mancinelli's apparent refusal to accept them telling about the philosophy of a humanist at the time, especially since tutoring jobs were highly desired well into the sixteenth century." Knowing what we know about humanism during the Renaissance
column18: there could be several reasons why he would refuse such a position. One could be that Mancinelli was solely interested in educating as many students as possible
column19: even if that meant refusing the benefits that came with "personal
column21: it seems to me that humanists would advocate a sort of "mass education" or public education that did not rely on social class (perhaps with the exception of Montaigne). Mancinelli's decision may very well have been working toward this ideal of education for all
column22: which had now been made possible by the advent of printing.`

column9: `I believe Mancinelli's willingness to continually correct and make changes to his printed texts shows his humanistic mindset that his personal experiences can change they way he learns and educates
column10: and what he knows to be true. He was not content with the knowledge that he knew to be true in the past and he continually wanted to improve his texts for himself and his students. On the other hand
column11: even if the mistakes in his texts really were the printer's errors
column12: it still shows the idea that education is always changing and can be improved. The invention of the printing press was revolutionary in more ways than one-- it allowed for a continual conversation between scholars. Mancinelli also proves his humanistic educational style by urging other scholars
column13: most likely other grammar scholars
column14: to inspect his work and provide commentary. This shows the he valued the importance of community and understanding others' opinions. I also think he embodies another human characteristic of diversity by teaching in several different cities; however
column15: I do not see this sense of diversity in his general teaching since he mainly teaches about grammar and its related subjects.\

column1: It is obvious that Mancinelli was a competitive writer and educator throughout his entire life
column2: which I think is extremely important to learning. However
column3: is this necessarily a humanistic characteristic in education/ in general?`
column6: `Mozilla/5.0 (Macintosh; Intel Mac OS X 10_11_2) AppleWebKit/601.3.9 (KHTML
column7: like Gecko) Version/9.0.2 Safari/601.3.9`
column12: \N

column9: `Hi
column10: CM! It is always difficult to speculate about motives absent specific evidence
column11: but in Mancinelli's case we have a rich body of prefaces and personal and business letters that address many of the points you raise. You are correct to see Mancinelli's motives in the context of public education (though at the period we have to remember that that left out most working class people and almost all women). I think the key to his attitude is in his small-town origins
column12: where a cadre of local notables wanted to improve education locally. It's unlikely than any of them could see to see the results we do as a result of printing --really widespread literacy. But Mancinelli  did recognize printing immediately as a tool for making his job easier and making his students' work easier too.`
column15: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0`

column9: `I feel as though this paragraph really captures the essence of Humanism. The two purposes of the work that Mancinelli mentions to his son are morals and Latin. This is a representation of the Humanist era because it was a movement from medieval times that began to focus more on the goodness of man. The teaching of Latin during this time was important as well since the Renaissance
column10: and the Humanism movement in particular
column11: stressed the newfound importance of language. Mentioning the different meanings of words between Humanism and feudal times is another representation of the movement away from medieval society and towards a new appreciation of Greek and Roman thought and of language. \

column1: However

column9: `You raise several points here
column10: Alissa
column11: all of which point to the last part of your comment
column12: the matter of competitiveness. This was certainly not new to humanist learning; indeed
column13: one of the things the early humanists most disliked about medieval scholasticism was the pettiness of the arguments back and forth. The humanist ideal was one of rhetorical truth achieved by argument
column14: to be sure
column15: but typically within a context of collaboration. Mancinelli's many scholarly commentaries were largely aimed at making the base text available to the broad public that printing made possible. \

column1: I'd have to think a little more about the ideal of diversity. Certainly what we mean by that would not fit the situation in Renaissance Italy. Mancinelli's moving around from city to city probably had more to do with careerism than a love of being in different places.`
column9: \N
`To take your last point first
column10: Elizabeth
column11: we do not have any good price data on Mancinelli's books (or indeed on most printing of the 15th century). It is clear
column12: however
column13: that the small textbook-type booklets he wrote for students were relatively cheap. As one of your colleagues remarked at section 3.05
column14: however
column15: this meant that he was aiming for a market of citizen schools
column16: not at the education of aristocrats.\

column1: As for the urge to correct
column2: this is common to most scholars
column3: but it was given new possibilities with the invention of printing. Printing meant that many more copies of an erroneous text could circulate
column4: but reprinting meant that there was a new opportunity --fueled by market competition-- to make the texts better in later editions.\

column1: Your point about acclaim vs. quailty is something I have thought a lot about. Printing made the manufacture of fame possible in a new way
column2: one that scholars of the period have discussed but not come to final conclusions about.`

column9: `Hi
column10: Paige. Your question is one of the big issues in the scholarship on the Renaissance. The relationship of humanism to the church is not an easy one to describe
column11: because there were so many different solutions
column12: almost as many as there were serious thinkers in the period. Mancinelli is writing on the eve of the Reformation
column13: when many intellectuals were dissatisfied with the corruption of the church and their relative inability to effect reforms. Manicnelli
column14: however
column15: seems to have been a pretty conformist type. He is very devoutly religious and does not seem to have felt there was any real or necessary break between classical scholarship and Christian orthodoxy. I suspect this was a common stance among humanists
column16: especially those of the second rank. It is worth remembering in this regard that
column17: although I have devoted an entire chapter to him
column18: Mancinelli was not one of the great thinkers of the period. He was a famous teacher (and most teachers are good but not necessarily great thinkers).`

column9: `The most important thing to keep in mind here is that the "printing revolution" was not like a political upheaval. We think of it as revolutionary because it did in fact change the world; but it happened slowly everywhere and at different speeds in different places. Gutenberg first printed around 1450; Italians only got the technology in the late 1460s
column10: and it did not really transform classrooms for another generation after that. Mancinelli offers a good study because he was an early adopter. And because he is attested as such. Many teachers probably experimented with print in a similar way
column11: but their little textbooks do not survive to tell us about it.`
column14: `Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:43.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/43.0`

column9: `You ask some big questions here
column10: and they are ones that the advent of printing threw into high relief. The new
column11: cheap
column12: and standardized textbooks made many classroom tasks easier and they made it easier for students to take work home; but they did not immediately cause a revolution in teaching methods
column13: mostly because teachers and schools were very conservative. Rather more than nowadays
column14: educators valued traditional methods.`

column9: `I'm not sure what you are getting at here
column10: Abdoul
column11: but you are certainly right that printing allowed the creation of textbooks as market objects in competition with each other for use in the schools. I don't think this resulted in making humanists into merchants or humanism into a commercial enterprise
column12: but it did mean that one part of the humanist achievement
column13: went on the market in a way that was not true before printing. This is the import of my title Humanism For Sale.\

column1: The Jesuits are the subject of a later chapter
column2: and you can actually read their educational work as an attempt to corner the market.`

`601`,`211`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.3`,`2016-02-04 11:23:29`,`2016-02-04 17:23:29`,`Hi, Emily. I don't think there is an either-or here. Good teachers adopt the best textbooks, and though there are many other things that go into marketing textbooks, class is not very overtly one of them. Certainly, private tuition was restricted to the wealthy --either aristocrats or well-to-do merchant families-- but the teacher will use the texts that best fits his/her students' needs. What differs is that a private tutor can use pretty much any text, manuscript or printed, and tailor the curriculum closely to one or two students, while a schoolmaster is going to find distinct advantages in using printed texts that are designed for use by many students in a single classroom.\
\
To your other point, Montaigne-style reflective reading and meditation, this was an ideal for most humanists, but it is largely a goal for intermediate and advanced students, not for grammar school kids.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:44.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/44.0`,``,`0`,`2`,`3`,\N
`602`,`223`,`Hannah.M.Adair`,`hmafzf@mail.missouri.edu`,``,`128.206.150.199`,`2016-02-04 11:24:23`,`2016-02-04 17:24:23`,`I find this to be an interesting addition to the history and story of Mancinelli. In his recreation of literature, we see the evolution of the thoughts, the structure, and the language. We now can also see that there is discrepancies between scholars of the same time period. The fact that he so painstakingly created these margin notes and commentary to only have them thrown out and disregarded is something that perhaps is more common place than not. \
\
Should we believe that perhaps other scholars provided  better recreations of the classics? For example, Erasmus or Montaigne, both scholars of Humanism. The idea that these scholars profited off of their rendition of the literature is something else that is intriguing. Selling not only the original, but your own original thoughts as well.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.3; WOW64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/48.0.2564.103 Safari/537.36`,``,`0`,`5860`,`4`,\N
`603`,`223`,`Hannah.M.Adair`,`hmafzf@mail.missouri.edu`,``,`128.206.148.78`,`2016-02-04 12:05:05`,`2016-02-04 18:05:05`,`I find that you bring up an interesting point here about the credibility of literature recreation, but also the individualism that is present within the recreations themselves. You bring into question the reliability of Mancinelli. If we compare his works to others like Erasmus or Montaigne, do we see that there is discrepancies among all of them? \
\
In addition, there is an interesting point brought up about the comments and references made in the margins. The idea that you not only buy the literature for the content of the creator, but for the content provided to you by the scholar. It is truly the 15th century version of peer-reviewed" in a sense. Also
column11: that those comments could be lost in "translation" and recreation during printing we bring into question the importance of content versus the method used to diffuse the content. Was printing a clean version more important than the content provided in the first?`

column9: `From what I gathered in this chapter

column11: but also stressed the need for correction. He contested the works of major authors and didn't take any of his own knowledge for granted. Mancinelli encouraged students to diversify their knowledge and opinions by looking at different interpretations of certain subjects. \

column1: I see many similarities between Mancinelli and Montaigne
column2: a humanist in Renaissance France. They both draw upon the ideas of contesting ancient works that were never before doubted
column3: discovering new knowledge at every point in life
column4: and being open to different opinions.\

column1: However
column2: in Chapter 25 "Sur l'education des enfants" in Book One of "Essais
column3:
Montaigne draws upon the importance of conversation between students and teachers. He says that is essential for students to question the teachings they are being taught in class. This can come from having discussions with the teacher or opening their mind to new worldly experiences. \
\
From what I gathered, Mancinelli mainly focuses on the discussion between teachers to figure out the best methods to teach students. He does not seem to mention much about the discussions in the classroom. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.3`,`2016-02-04 12:33:34`,`2016-02-04 18:33:34`,`You are pointing to a crucial matter of the new economy of print, Hannah, in that a second or subsequent edition of a base text that has been reworked by a new editor or commentator is offering what we would call added value" on the marketplace. This is new to printing
column4: made possible by the way in which books in sizable editions compete for customers. Just in this case
column6: authors like Erasmus and Mancinelli were attempting to profit (whether materially or just in prestige) from a humanist text that had already become a classic. \

column1: Several of your classmates have pointed to the matter of scholarly controversy and argumentation. This is another case where printing really made a difference
column2: since a given argument could get a very wide audience through print.\

column1: As for "clean" texts
column2: that is important only if the text is authoritative in some way
column3: so the editions of classics got reworked over and over in the search for a better understanding of the original author's language and intent.`

column9: `As the images in this section clearly show
column10: the window-in-frame layouts often resolved into multiple windows -- like rafts that seem to float on a sea of commentary. This created a lot of work for the typesetters; but it was actually valued as a design element by scholars who used the differing arrangements of the double-page spread mnemonically
column11: to help them find passages they had seen before. The multiplication of index notes in the outer margins served something of the same function. This should remind us that reading and information-retrieval in the early years of printing did not depend so much on careful pagination and indexing as on the visual memory of expert readers.`

column9: `Your point about the relation between text
column10: the author
column11: and moral character is intriguing and essential to the study of humanism.  This triadic relation shows to what extent humanists tried to produce perfected works.  This idealistic view places a lot of pressure on the humanist individual.  It seems somewhat ironic because literature at this time was supposed to be a source of free thinking and an outlet for thinkers to come and express views that were opposing the Church. Relating Christian moral values to such works seems contrary to the goal of humanism: to focus on how aspects such as intelligence and nature influences the individual as opposed to how God influences the individual.`

column9: `You draw a useful comparison with Montaigne

column13: and the first edition of his Essays came out only in 1580

column9: `This is an interesting anecdote. It is important to acknowledge life before the printing press and the true impact it had on people. column9: `The opposition was never quite as sharp as this
column10: Stephanie. Historical scholarship on the importance of the religious dimension of Renaissance humanism has varied a lot over the years
column11: but in recent decades we have come to realize that many humanists were pretty content with traditional religious values and even strictures. I think the essential novelty of humanism was not to judge truth or human value solely on religious grounds
column12: but to admit to other sources of truth and to argue for a kind of natural morality that does not depend on religion for validation or even guidance. This is not to say there were no more radical and even anti-religious humanists
column13: merely that there were many who did not see much conflict at all between humanist and religious morality. Mancinelli clearly stands at this
column14: more conservative end of the spectrum.`

column9: `I think it is interesting too
column10: Julia
column11: not only because it does reflect fairly widespread complaints about printers and publishers who hijack an author's intent or misrepresnt his text
column12: but also in this case because Pellisson is writing in the 1520s
column13: when the benefits and dangers of going to press should have been obvious to most authors. It is speculation on my part
column14: but I suspect that in this case Pellisson (still in his 20s) was flattered that a printer would want to publsih his text and let it go to press without careful supervision.`

column9: `Reading this initially lead me to focus on the concept of creation. Creating an idea is a difficult task because the creator is using his/her own innate imagination to bring something new into existence. Now
column10: this is the entire premise of the Renaissance
column11: to create new ideas and new values for life with inspiration from the past
column12: in the midst of technological inventions that aided in the transmission of the later. My mind then drifted to the concept of â€œreproductionâ€. In this context
column13: â€œreproductionâ€ is unoriginal and
column14: in a sense
column15: unfortunate. It pulls the readers attention away from the beauty of the creation process and the authenticity of the authors own language
column16: due to the many errors Mancinelli mentioned occurred as a result of mass printing. Why did you choose to use these words to describe printers? I ask this question because the printing press was a novelty that opened the doors for knowledge to be transmitted literally across cultures and across nations. I see this as an asset
column17: not a draw back. This phrase is essentially putting the creator (humans) against machine (printing press). Remember the creator was the one who brought the machine into existence. I feel I am pushing the boarders to the philosophical level
column18: which many humanists would be proud of. I cannot even begin to imagine our generation surviving without the basic necessity of print. There are pros and cons to the argument. Mancinelli praises the product of the printing press
column19: that is the mass transmission of knowledge
column20: but critics its frequent errors and the constant need to update the text. He enjoys the many benefits the printing press has allowed for in the realm of teaching and education
column21: but discusses that it also â€œgave some fairly ordinary teachers in Mancinelli's generation (and ever since) the opportunity for a permanent
column22: or at least long-term literary reputation specifically as textbook writers.â€`

column9: `Mosley's articles on "dabbbing

In my opinion, there must be an equilibrium of sort between education and innovation, especially from a humanistic perspective. While bulk printing allowed more students access to education, it also forced students to learn in a specified way that seems to contradict many humanist teachings. You touch on this with your comment that speedy learning of this sort is most beneficial to the student who is a quick study". While Mancinelli claims to be a humanist
column11: it appears that as he becomes more invested in himself and innovating the "humanist classroom"
column12: he loses sight of the ideals that shape humanistic education.`

column16: like Gecko) Chrome/48.0.2564.97 Safari/537.36`

column9: `Innovation is never quite this radical in the fifteenth century and even less so in conservative areas like language teaching. While it is true that printing had the potential to standardize instruction across schools and whole regions
column10: that happened only slowly and certainly did not come to fruition in Mancinelli's lifetime. Moreover
column11: Mancinelli never abandoned his humanist ideals. He was happy to adopt the new technology
column12: but I think it was pretty much impossible for someone in his generation to make a radical break with the ideals he inherited from earlier humanists.`

column9: `Hi Dr. Gehl

column9: `To start with your last remark first
column10: Khalil: Some commentators at the time insisted that having print copies so easily available would make memorizing less necessary and they worried about its effects. The ancient Greeks had the same worry
column11: or claimed to
column12: about writing itself. And of course
column13: educational alarmists now claim that digital media are ruining the abilities of young people to think and read reflectively. The difference is that now we have neurological instruments that let us measure such things. We will know (to some degree) about how present day young people differ from their elders and even more about the next generation; what we do not know is how the earlier technologies changed ancient or early modern brains. \

column1: Regulation in the Renaissance was --to our eyes-- unimaginably inefficient. Local governments could keep surveillance on and regulate local trade
column2: but there were no systems to extend that control very far. Printing eventually spawned many attempts at press regulation and censorship
column5: it was not at all effective in the fifteenth and early sixteenth century; and even later
column6: you just had to go to the next town with a willing printer to get something into print. Control of the market for school books was more effective in the sense that teachers had to approve what was used
column7: but there was a lot of competition. The only case of a textbook that was really widely imposed is described in Chapter 5 below
column9: and even there some teachers did not conform entirely.`

Dennis Rhodes points out (La Bibliofilia 117 (2015), pp. 231-234) that at least two grammar books published there now survive in single copies. That one grammar by the internationally known Giovanni Battista Cantalicio (d. 1515) and another by the obscure Angelo Fino (dates unknown) survive in this way suggests that the city had a micro-market for single editions of such works, presumably created at mid 16th century for a local school. Cantalicio is in fact another example of a Perugian master (he taught grammar there ca. 1488) whose textbooks achieved international status because they were publsihed in Siena, Rome, Venice and elsewhere. The Perugian edition mentioned by Rhodes is the only one known to have been printed there, and it dates from some years after the author's death. `,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:47.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/47.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`5`,\N `634`,`18`,`Paul F. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.3`,`2016-07-12 14:17:03`,`2016-07-12 19:17:03`,`It will be clear from this section that my approach to humanism in this book is largely commercial. As comments here and again at the end of the book (in chapter 8) reveal, however, this is only a partial view, and many scholars take exception to my emphases. The recent republication of Maury Feld's several essays on early printing remind me that he presented a richly nuanced view of the commercial dimensions of humanism (very limited in his view) in a series of essays that appeared in the Harvard Library Bulletin. See now, however, M.D. Feld, Printing and Humanism in Renaissance Italy: Essays in the Revival of the Pagan Gods (Rome: Roma nel Rinascimento, 2015), especially pp. 176-181, i.e. the section of chapter 6 headed, Cottage Enterprise -- Court Enterprise."`

Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.3`,`2016-09-27 08:25:32`,`2016-09-27 13:25:32`,`Correction: As EDIT16 (the online bibliography of sixteenth-century Italian imprints) progresses, we now know of three other editions of Cantalicio's textbook printed in Perugia. One of these editions is represented in a single surviving copy and the others have two and four known copies each (that is, known to date, of course). This argues further for a local tradition of a schoolmaster or masters in the 1570s and 80s who adopted this textbook, either for its intrinsic value or because of the tradition that Cantalicio had taught at Perugia. Another locality where the text got editions quite late is Florence. Then too, three of the rare surviving copies of the late Perugian editions survive in libraries at Assisi (which is just a few miles from Perugia), suggesting that there may have been a school there which adopted Cantalicio's textbook some 70 years after his death.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:49.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/49.0`,``,`633`,`2`,`5`,\N `642`,`294`,`Paul F. It is now clear to me that the earliest editions supervised directly by Cantalicio bear both the title Summa perutilis... (on a title or cover page) and Canones grammatices (in the caption tile to the preface supplied by Cantalicio). The usage of canones is interesting, since this word is used in the titles of books in many disciplines (law, canon law and medicine most prominently), but I have not found any other writer on grammar who employs this rather elevated term to describe grammatical rules.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0`,``,`640`,`5`,`19`,\N `652`,`169`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.45`,`2016-11-30 10:24:39`,`2016-11-30 16:24:39`,`Further on Cantalicio, see my notes on para 19 below.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`2`,\N `653`,`169`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.45`,`2016-11-30 10:29:53`,`2016-11-30 16:29:53`,`This practice of avoiding citations of contentious contemporary grammarians' opinions was taken up again by the Jesuit grammarian Manuel Alvares, on whom see chapter 5 below, esp. sections 5.01 to 5.05.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`18`,\N `654`,`321`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.45`,`2017-01-03 06:44:02`,`2017-01-03 12:44:02`,`The classic reading of the early humanists' transition to validating the use of Italian vernaculars is still Hans Baron's, best consulted in his Crisis of the Early Italian Renaissance, 2nd ed (1966), 338-351.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:50.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/50.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`5`,\N `655`,`387`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.45`,`2017-02-08 11:50:10`,`2017-02-08 17:50:10`,`Since Humanism for Sale was originally published (2008), the field of Jesuit emblem studies has flourished. Gehl`,`gehlp@newberry.org`,``,`64.107.55.3`,`2017-04-03 11:41:59`,`2017-04-03 16:41:59`,`This project is remarked by Paola Farenga (cit. in comment to section 3.09, para 3 above, p. 427-428), who assumes that publishing such lists of works was a response to 'pirated' or unauthorized editions. In my reading, however, the early lists are straightforward advertising, while the later ones signal a shift by Mancinelli or his publishers to creating unified sets of his works for the more sophisticated, international market for which Venetians printed. It is really not necessary to see this as a response to unauthorized printings.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:52.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/52.0`,``,`0`,`2`,`1`,\N `661`,`345`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.45`,`2017-04-14 06:03:46`,`2017-04-14 11:03:46`,`The realm of non-Latin, non-elite printing extended to an enormous variety of print products in the vernacular. In a thoughtful and important essay, Alberto Cevolini (cit. in comments to section 0.01 above, esp. pp. 289-90) describes this process of maturation, with specific reference to commonplace books, as a fundamental change in the technology of reading and study. His larger essay paints much the same picture for dictionaries and encyclopedias; and he includes a wide range of indexing and cataloging tools in the same transformation of learning.`,`0`,`1`,`Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; WOW64; rv:53.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/53.0`,``,`0`,`5`,`2`,\N `666`,`155`,`Paul Gehl`,`pgehl@rcn.com`,``,`205.178.2.45`,`2017-06-01 20:11:43`,`2017-06-02 01:11:43`,`An interesting critique both of the Donat and Doctrinale and of the early humanist attempts (like Guarino's) to replace them was penned in the 1470s by Tommaso Ferrando, a printer and grammarian at Brescia who claimed to have devised an entirely new method of teaching grammar but never published his invention.
